scenes.location: A picturesque vineyard overlooking the Amalfi coast
scenes.content:
My chest tightens as Marco’s silhouette emerges from between the grapevines. The fading light sharpens his outline, and I feel my breath catch at the sight of him stepping into the clearing where I stand. Rows of lush greenery stretch towards the coast, but it's his presence that steals all the oxygen.

"You know this place holds more than just wine," Marco says, approaching with a warmth in his voice that makes me shiver despite the summer evening's gentle breeze. His words echo a shared history from years ago, and I can’t help but wonder what ghosts might be awakened here today.

He takes off his jacket and drapes it over a nearby wooden post, revealing a casual shirt rolled up to show muscle definition beneath tanned skin. The sight unsettles me as he moves with grace through the vineyard setting—a stark reminder of another time when these grounds were alive with our laughter and games.

"Marco," I start, turning my gaze towards him but not quite meeting it directly. "I don’t want to pretend this evening isn’t filled with ghosts from our past." My voice is steady, sharp edges cutting through the space between us as if we’re navigating a minefield of unspoken truths.

He pauses for a moment before smiling softly, that trademark charm playing across his features like sunlight dancing upon water. "There’s no point ignoring them," he acknowledges, finally stepping closer and leaning against one of the wooden posts beside him.

The sound of laughter drifts down from somewhere above us, likely a group of tourists enjoying their evening wine tasting session up on the vineyard’s terrace. It serves as an odd reminder that while I’m grappling with my own demons here in this place, others enjoy merely relaxing and sipping on something pleasurable.

"Let’s walk," Marco suggests, his eyes flickering towards one direction where the vineyards seem to lead into the heart of rolling hills and more grapevines. His invitation hangs between us—unspoken, yet inviting a journey not just through these rows but into our shared memories too.

I nod silently to myself, deciding it’s time to face whatever ghosts may arise from this adventure together instead of running away from them like I used to do when we first met years ago. We begin walking side by side in silence at first, each step taking us further down the path where once we could find solace and laughter.

The terrain beneath my feet shifts as we leave the main vineyard pathway for a smaller one that winds around clusters of grapevines, their leaves rustling gently with our passing. Despite the serenity of this setting and the ease between us now, there’s still an underlying tension—an unspoken acknowledgment that everything has changed but hasn’t also.

After several minutes, Marco breaks the quietness once again, his voice carrying over my shoulder as he asks, "What do you remember most about being here before?"

I pause, considering how to answer honestly without exposing too much of myself in this moment. My mind flashes back to a simpler time when wine tasting was just an afternoon activity and not laden with the weight of unresolved emotions.

"The freedom," I admit softly, glancing at him from the corner of my eye. "Here, there were no divorce cases or family secrets looming over our heads—just you and me enjoying life."

He smiles faintly, the corners of his lips twitching in understanding and perhaps a hint of melancholy too. "You always saw things so clearly," he murmurs appreciatively. It’s a compliment that feels both comforting and disarming all at once.

As we continue walking, I notice Marco’s hand brushing lightly against mine—a casual gesture but one laden with meaning and memories. The touch sends shivers down my spine, and our fingers graze each other before they separate again almost as quickly as they touched. This fleeting connection leaves me wanting more while also reminding me of the boundaries we’ve set for ourselves.

Finally, Marco stops at a small clearing where sunlight filters through the leaves above, casting intricate patterns on the ground below. He turns to face me squarely now under this canopy of light and vines, his expression unreadable but intense. "You know I’d never force you into anything," he says quietly yet firmly, those last words carrying an unspoken promise that echoes throughout our history.

I meet his gaze steadily, feeling a mix of emotions swirling inside: gratitude for his understanding, desire to break free from past constraints, and fear of opening up too much again. The moment feels charged—ripe with possibility but also fraught with risk.

"That’s why I’m here," I reply, my voice resolute despite the turmoil within me. "Because this time, I want us to figure out if there can be something new between us without falling into old patterns."

His eyes search mine for a long moment before finally nodding in agreement, his acceptance both a relief and a challenge all wrapped up in one look. The air around us thickens with anticipation as we stand there under the dappled light, each of us waiting to see what will come next.

And then, without breaking eye contact, Marco closes the distance between us, reaching out again but this time not pulling away when our fingers meet once more and entwine beneath the vines. The connection sends a jolt through me, grounding me in the present yet tethering me back to memories long buried deep inside my heart.

Our hands still linked, I deflate slightly, feeling the tension ease slightly as we take another step forward together into whatever lies ahead—this time without looking back.

Reaching out to steady him, I feel Marco’s heartbeat sync with mine beneath our intertwined fingers. The moment feels frozen in time as his eyes meet mine, softening at the edges even though they hold a depth that speaks of buried pain and unresolved grief.

"Remember this place?" His voice lowers, reverting almost to the tone it had back then—as if he’s speaking to someone from years ago rather than me. It’s an echo of a past memory I’d tried to push deep into my mind.

Nodding slowly, I trace back to that tumultuous week before Sofia and Dante’s engagement party. The same spot where Marco had confessed about his brother’s tragic death in the midst of a rainstorm. “Of course,” I murmur, barely audible but still clear across the space between us.

His hand tightens around mine, pulling me deeper into the grapevine rows. "We were supposed to be just co-workers then," he says, his grip loosening briefly before tightening again, as if needing that physical contact to keep himself grounded in the present reality of us together. His thumb brushes over my knuckles, sending a familiar shiver up my spine.

Inhaling deeply through the crisp air scented with ripe grapes and blooming flowers, I remember how he sought me out regardless of what it meant for either of our careers. "But you didn’t let us just be co-workers," I recall aloud.

"Couldn’t leave things unsaid," Marco admits with a small shake of his head, the sunlight catching on strands of dark hair as he swivels to face me fully. “Every time I walked away from you back then, I ended up coming right back.”

His admission unearths feelings long buried and half-forgotten beneath layers of professional distance and personal heartache. "So why did you?" I challenge softly, my voice tinged with a mix of curiosity and vulnerability.

Instead of retreating into his usual humor or evasion tactics, Marco meets my eyes squarely, offering no immediate reply. In those silent moments, the weight of everything—from our past to what lies ahead—becomes palpable but manageable somehow.

"Does this mean we’re starting over?" His question carries both an invitation and a plea for clarity, breaking the silence with the simplicity of those words hanging in the silence between us.

For a moment, I consider the gravity of his inquiry—this chance to restart our story amidst a backdrop of renewed understanding and mutual respect. Inhaling sharply through my nose, I feel emotions swirling inside me: relief at being able to address unfinished business; fear over risking another fall from grace; desire for something real between us again after years apart.

Yet looking into his eyes now filled with that same glimmer of hope he’d once shared with me during stormy nights in Amalfi, I know there’s no turning back. “I think it does,” I respond truthfully, my heart echoing the sentiment before I can fully articulate it aloud.

Before delving deeper into the implications of our renewed connection, Marco pulls a small envelope from his pocket and hands it to me with a serious expression. “This is why I needed to talk to you today,” he says, his voice steady but tinged with urgency. As my fingers grasp the crisp paper, I realize that whatever lies inside could change everything once more—and we both know there’s no going back now.

Looking down at the envelope, I feel a knot tighten in my stomach. “What is it?” I ask tentatively, my eyes lifting to meet his once again.

Marco’s gaze softens as he watches me take in the weight of what might be inside. “Let’s find out,” he says simply, offering no further explanation but leaving room for us both to figure things out together.

The morning light filtered through salt-crusted windows of my childhood memories as Marco and I walked toward a small clearing in the vineyard. Each step felt deliberate, like retracing footprints etched deep into soft dirt. Our hands remained intertwined, his heat grounding me.

“Are you okay?” he asked softly. He knew I was more than fine—no words needed to shatter this fragile connection.

I looked down at our entwined fingers, surprised by how natural they felt despite everything I should know better than to allow. Past choices pressed against me for a moment before dissipating as I stepped forward again, pulling us deeper into the secluded corner where no one could see but the sun.

“You ever think back on why we were such good friends?” His voice was nostalgic, drawing memories like a well springing forth from the earth below. “You remember when we used to run through these vines?”

The faintest breeze carried the scent of grapes and soil—a familiar aroma that always brought me back to childhood summers spent here with Abuela Lena tending her garden.

“Sometimes,” I admitted quietly, my throat tight. My fingers tightened around his hand as if holding onto a lifeline.

His gaze met mine, his eyes crinkling slightly in memory. “Same.” He replied after a moment of contemplation.

The silence between us now felt less like an obstacle than a comfort, each breath more measured than before. The tension that had knotted my muscles earlier eased, replaced by something softer—a sense of shared history threading us together despite everything that has happened since then.

We stepped closer as if drawn by an invisible force, and I felt the warmth radiating from Marco’s body even through our clothes. His hand still gripped mine lightly, a silent promise or maybe just another tie to what we’ve lost along the way.

“I can’t believe how much has changed,” I muttered, squeezing his hand tighter as a breeze rustled the leaves overhead. My pulse kicks sideways with conflicting emotions—wanting him and yet fearing it.

As he watched me curiously now, his eyes held a depth beyond blue—echoes of stormy nights and shared laughter in Amalfi. “What’s it like for you?” I asked hesitantly, needing to know how much of our past remained unscarred by the passage of time.

His face softened further at the question. His lips parted before he formed the words. “It feels just as surreal,” he admitted quietly, looking down before meeting my eyes again with more resolve this time. There was a new understanding between us now; one that acknowledged the complexity of our pasts but also the potential for something different moving forward.

I took in a breath I hadn’t realized was caught in my chest, feeling the knots untangle further as we faced each other directly. Our hands still connected, every fiber wanting to close the gap and pull him into an embrace that could erase years of distance. Yet there was caution—a reminder of all that led us here.

“We’ve come so far since then,” Marco murmured quietly. His grip on my hand tightened slightly as he looked away for a moment before meeting my eyes again. His gaze flickered over my face with curiosity mingling under steady blue eyes. “You’re stronger than you think,” he said softly, like a private admission.

The corners of my mouth turned up slightly, grateful for this moment of shared truth. “And you’re braver,” I countered softly, watching his expression shift—pride and humility intertwining briefly in those familiar pools before he smiled gently back at me.

With every step bringing us closer under the sprawling vine canopy, there was a palpable sense that this moment could be more than another steppingstone. It felt like we were both ready to move forward despite everything hovering between us.

As I looked into his eyes one last time before leaning my head towards him ever so slightly, our lips grazed hesitantly—it was as if the whole world shifted beneath our feet for a moment. The weight of past and present momentarily merged into one breathless instant where we belonged together despite everything that had happened.

Just as he pulled back to look at me again, his eyes searching with an intensity that left no room for doubt—Marco leaned in for another kiss, this time without pulling away or hesitating. The connection felt charged and urgent, each sensation magnifying the other until we were both lost in it.

In the split second before lips met once more under open sky, time held its breath along with us. All that existed was this moment of shared intimacy—a reaffirmation of all building between us since our first meeting at Amalfi.

As I pulled back slightly after another kiss, my heart beating faster now under his touch, I could feel the shift in dynamics between us. There’s no going back now—to me, it felt like a new beginning wrapped up in an old friendship rediscovered and rekindled.

Gianna's voice cut through sharply from behind us: “If anyone tries to stand in our way, I won’t hesitate.” Her stance was firm and protective as she strode toward us. Our entwined hands tightened, the warmth of Marco’s grip a reassurance that we faced whatever came next together.

Her arrival shattered the spell, leaving me standing there under the golden light of dawn, my pressure in my ears rises with the knowledge that everything between us had shifted in ways I couldn’t fully grasp yet.

scenes.content:
My knuckles turn white as I grip the railing tightly, feeling the rough texture bite into my skin. The storm clouds gather on Marco’s brow from across the balcony, each dark mass a reminder of all that's shifted since our first kiss.

“You’re still here,” he says behind me, his voice carrying a mix of surprise and resignation that sends shivers down my spine. I turn to face him; our eyes lock across the distance between us.

“I didn’t expect you to leave.” My words are sharp like legal briefs, but there’s an undercurrent of something else—a softness born from this shared time together. Stuck. The word hangs heavy between us, a reminder of all that's shifted since our first kiss. My heart flutters with conflicting emotions as I watch the storm clouds gather on his brow.

“Why did you ask me to help again?” He turns to look at me now, those piercing eyes searching for something deeper beneath my surface.

“We both needed someone,” I counter, choosing my words carefully. “You wanted an unbiased third party, and I…” My voice trails off as I struggle with honesty. Truth is dangerous, especially after what we’ve uncovered about our past entanglements. He sighs softly before answering, his gaze drifting back toward the horizon where waves crash against the cliffs far below us.

“Trust,” he says, his word echoing in my ears like a promise made long ago that’s finally found its way back into my grasp. I tilt my head up, meeting his eyes once more.

“What happened between us,” he begins tentatively, “wasn’t just about planning the wedding.” His voice is low and earnest now, cutting through the easy banter we’ve shared thus far in favor of something rawer and more real.

“It was never just that,” I confirm quietly, my fingers curling around the railing. My knuckles turn white as I grip tighter, trying to anchor myself amid this swirling sea of emotions and memories.

“Why did you choose divorce law?” Marco’s question slices through the air like a blade. It strikes at the heart of what has haunted me since this connection reignited—a fear that my career choice might be nothing more than collateral damage from a failed relationship.

“Because I can help people,” I reply, each word deliberate and steady to shield myself behind professionalism. “They need guidance.”

“I didn’t want to relive it all again.” His I study him harder slightly, challenging me, pushing for an answer that doesn’t come easily.

“They just become another case,” I force out through gritted teeth, feeling the lie burn on my tongue. My stomach churns with guilt as I remember all those papers I signed without knowing whose hands they’d end up in.

“You make it sound so simple.” His tone is wry but there’s a sincerity beneath that bites sharply at me.

“It isn’t,” I snap back defensively, wishing there was another way to explain this tangled web of past and present.

“Then why can't we be honest?” he presses further, his eyes searching for more truth than what’s on the surface. “Why do you keep it hidden?”

“I’ve been hiding from myself.” His question hits too close to home. I fill my lungs, trying to steady my nerves.

“What is there to hide if only we are truthful?” I breathe out softly, daring him—and myself—to face everything lying dormant in this moment.

“Let’s start by telling each other what we believe,” Marco suggests gently, offering me an opening to lay down some ground rules. He steps closer, his eyes steady on mine.

“I can live with that.” My resolve hardens as I agree, feeling the weight of my silence lift just a bit as promises and secrets begin to unravel between us like threads on fabric pulled taut.

“We’ve both been playing this game for too long,” he says firmly, breaking the stalemate in our conversation. “It’s time to face what we want.” He turns fully toward me now, standing close enough that I can feel the heat radiating off his body even through the cool evening air.

“I know,” I whisper back, my voice barely audible as those stormy eyes lock onto mine once more. This could be a turning point—either opening up the floodgates or closing them tighter.

“Do you?” he asks with renewed urgency, stepping in until there’s no space left between us but our breaths intertwined.

“Then let's start with telling each other the truth from now on.” His words are quiet but powerful, setting up chains of command and expectation between us. As he nods in agreement, stepping back slightly to give me space, the tension in the air lifts just enough for something else to take root—hope. Hope that maybe we can break free from our past entanglements and forge a new path together.

“We both know there’s still so much more than this,” Marco adds quietly as the sun sets fully behind us, casting everything in shadows tinged with orange hues of fire.

“Yes,” I admit finally, letting go of my defenses for now. “Let’s start our new chapter honestly and see where it takes us.”

“I won’t let our history dictate our future.” My eyes lock with his as the sun dips behind the horizon. With that, a small smile tugs at the corners of his mouth once more. The balcony seems to grow warmer as we stand there together, ready to face whatever comes next.

“Tell me something I don’t know,” he murmurs softly, breaking the silence between us with a candid admission that sends shivers down my spine.

“I’ve missed this,” I reply quietly, allowing myself to feel it fully—a connection built on truth and mutual understanding. As the stars begin to twinkle above in a clear sign of new beginnings, we take one step forward into this uncertain but hopeful future.

I step into the dimly lit wine cellar near Positano with a cautious stride, my hands clenching around the glass bottle. A mix of anticipation and lingering tension swirls inside me as I take in Marco’s presence. The earthy scent of aging oak and fermenting grapes engulfs us as the light from our handheld lantern casts long shadows over the rows of stacked bottles.

“You’ve always known your way around wine,” I say, my tone sharp yet unguarded—a nod to familiarity masked by the crisp air between us.

Marco’s eyes glint with a familiar warmth that catches me off guard. “And you, Lena.” His voice is soft but tinged with an undercurrent of something deeper. A shiver runs down my spine as I suppress the urge to brush it off and focus on uncorking the bottle before us. The cork pops with an almost triumphant click that echoes in the quiet space.

As we pour the rich, golden liquid into two glasses, our movements synchronize seamlessly—a testament to years of knowing each other’s rhythms. Yet beneath this ease lies a layer of uncertainty that pricks at my nerves.

“To new beginnings,” Marco offers, raising his glass with a gentle smile.

I counter with, “To rediscovering old ones.” We clink our glasses in a momentary connection that speaks volumes without words. We sip in silence for a while, letting the flavors of the wine speak instead. The taste lingers on my tongue like a promise—a reminder of what we once were and have become again.

“Why did you choose this particular bottle?” Marco asks curiously, drawing my attention back to the present with his voice.

I gesture towards the label, tracing over the vintage year etched in ink. “This is from the same year our paths first crossed,” I reveal quietly, letting the shared history hang between us like an unspoken truth. His eyes soften at this admission, and I feel my own defenses start to crumble.

“I remember that day vividly,” he muses aloud, his voice laced with nostalgia as he stares into the depths of his glass. “We were both so full of life and potential.” A pause follows before he meets my gaze, searching for something in me—in us—that’s long been buried beneath layers of professional distance.

“What do you think happened?” I finally ask, unable to ignore the question gnawing at my insides—a query about fate and choices rather than past regrets or missed opportunities. “Do you think we’re here for that reason?”

Marco’s gaze locks with mine again, and I see the myriad emotions swirling there—wonder mixed with wariness, hesitation balanced by determination. “Maybe,” he concedes softly, his eyes never leaving mine even to search deeper into me than ever before.

“We have to believe in second chances,” I whisper back, my voice unwavering but tinged with conviction. His eyes flicker with a mix of emotions—hope interwoven with doubts, yet something more—a silent acknowledgment that we’re both willing to try despite the risks.

The wine slips down my throat smoothly now, each drop a reminder of this moment—a chance at something more than obligation and professional courtesy. The silence between us lengthens as we grapple with these thoughts, each sip of wine becoming more than just liquid—it’s the embodiment of our shared journey, past, present, and perhaps future.

“What worries you most about moving forward?” I ask gently, the question hanging in the air like an unspoken weight. His brow furrows slightly before he answers honestly, his voice steady despite the internal struggle evident behind his words. “Fear of repeating past mistakes,” Marco admits softly, a vulnerability that sends ripples through me.

We both know those fears run deep for us—fears born from pain and misunderstandings. The silence between us lengthens as we share another sip of wine, letting its rich flavor blend into our conversation and promise us both forward.

“Me too,” I reply softly, my voice barely audible even in this quiet space where whispers carry like promises. Our hands remain joined as we turn back towards one another, the lantern flickering between us no longer enough to illuminate the depth of what lies ahead—only a mutual readiness to face whatever that might be.

“We can’t afford to let fear dictate our choices,” I state firmly, my eyes locking onto his with a steely determination. He nods slowly, understanding written in every line of his body.

The lantern light flickers as we step out of the wine cellar, casting long shadows behind us. The cool night air hits me like a reminder of what lies ahead—uncertainty and possibility intertwined in equal measure. We walk back towards the villa in silence, our steps synchronized but our minds racing with thoughts of where this journey might lead.

scenes.location: Villa dining room with stormy views
scenes.content:
The storm clouds gather outside, painting ominous strokes across the horizon like a dark canvas ready to unleash its fury. I stand by the table with a plate of caprese salad before me, my stomach tightening as if Marco’s presence alone can summon tempests.

“Rain,” he says quietly beside me, his voice low and contemplative.

I nod without turning to face him. “You were always good at predicting weather.” It’s not a question but an observation heavy with unspoken memories.

“The kind that comes rolling in from the sea,” he adds softly, looking out over the turbulent view. I pick up my fork and stab a tomato slice, letting the basil leaves shift and curl around the silverware. The coolness of the cheese against my fingers sends another shiver down my spine.

“He used to tell me storms are like emotions—big, unpredictable, but necessary sometimes,” Marco says with a touch of melancholy that colors his voice. “I wish I could have shared those lessons.”

An involuntary sigh escapes me as I set down the fork and turn towards him finally. We face each other across the table under the silent threat of raindrops outside.

“What was it really like to lose someone so close?” The question is heavy on my tongue, but it needs asking. It’s clear I’m not the only one carrying burdens from that fateful summer three years ago.

Marco's lips curve into a slight smile, still not meeting my eyes. “You always knew how to find the right words,” he says gently, his gaze finally turning to mine.

“I think about those days constantly.” Marco adds softly. “Luca was more than just a brother; he was a friend. My mentor.”

“Divorce papers.” The words slip out before I can stop them, echoing old pain in my voice.

His my gaze sharpens momentarily but soften as understanding washes over him. He moves closer, placing a hand over mine, which is still holding onto my fork for dear life. The warmth from his skin seeps into mine, offering comfort I didn’t know I craved.

“Marco...” I begin hesitively, not knowing how best to articulate the tangle of feelings inside me. I release my grip on the fork and turn fully towards him now, seeking out his eyes for answers as much as offering them my truth.

He nods slowly but then pulls me close, an unspoken promise in each careful breath. The storm outside intensifies, raindrops pelting against glass like impatient beats of time moving forward relentlessly. It mirrors the urgency inside me to face whatever uncertainty looms ahead. Yet for once, facing it doesn’t seem so daunting with this unexpected support.

“What happened that day?” he asks softly, breaking the silence now filled with shared history and future uncertainties alike. His question reaches deep into my past; a door I thought long sealed now creaks open at the slightest nudge of his words.

"I couldn't bring myself to tell you everything that night," I confessed, my voice wavering slightly as I looked down at the table.

Marco’s hand tightens over mine in silent support. “Remember when we talked about your brother during one stormy night here?” The memory is vivid as if it happened yesterday instead of years ago. “I was handling divorce papers for his family then.”

“We both knew there were more questions left,” he says thoughtfully, a silent acknowledgment that we’ve only just begun to scratch the surface.

“Three years have passed since then.” I reflect aloud, my voice steady now despite the flurry of emotions swirling inside me. “But some things don’t change so easily.”

“No,” Marco agrees quietly, his gaze tracing over my face with an intensity far beyond casual interest. "They don't."

The moment stretches thickly between us as the rain becomes almost deafening—a drumbeat urging us into uncharted territory together. But in this moment of stillness amidst chaos, it feels like possibility rather than fear.

“And yet,” I say firmly, lifting my hand to trace his jawline lightly in a gesture that’s both tender and daring, “that doesn’t mean we can't start anew either.”

“Let’s start here,” Marco murmurs against my temple as he holds me close, grounding us firmly in this present moment. The words are simple yet resounding—a declaration that marks the true beginning of something new and uncharted for both of us.

The rain continues to pour outside in a relentless torrent, but inside our little sanctuary by the window, it feels like sunshine breaking through after endless darkness. The heavy air between us now carries more hope than fear; each droplet hitting glass now seems to echo that newfound resolve within our hearts.

I breathe in deeply, feeling his warmth enveloping me—both literally and metaphorically—and breathe through it as I respond:

“Here.” My voice steady yet trembling with unbridled emotion. “Together.”

With those words hanging softly between us like an open promise, we lean in for another kiss—a brief but powerful moment that seals this resolution both physically and emotionally.

But there’s still work to be done; more stories to share, shadows to confront together. For now though—this is enough. This is a start.

As I pull away from him, my eyes meet his with a mix of determination and vulnerability. The storm outside rages on, but the room remains quiet—filled only with the sound of our breathing and the promise of what lies ahead.

scenes.content:
My hands tremble as I clasp them together beneath the table, trying to hide my anxiety from Marco. The air around us crackles with tension, and the steady hum of the trattoria’s background noise is no comfort at all.

"What's this?" Marco asks, his voice sharp and accusatory, pointing directly at my menu without looking up yet. His gaze remains fixed on me, as if he needs something tangible to pin down his question rather than ask it outright.

I fidget with a napkin in my lap before meeting his intense stare. "I... ordered what I usually get here."

"But why would you choose something so predictable?" His voice holds an edge that tells me he means more than just the food.

"Because it's familiar," I reply flatly, my tone sharper than intended. "It tastes good."

He leans in closer, a dangerous gleam in his eye. "Familiarity can be comforting when you're trying to shield yourself from something... unfamiliar and unsettling."

I clench my jaw, refusing to let him read the emotion swirling behind my eyes. Instead, I fixate on the salt shaker at our corner of the table.

"Is this about what I do for a living?" I ask, my voice cracking despite my best efforts to remain composed.

Marco nods slowly. "Exactly."

"I understand why you might be uncomfortable," I begin carefully, choosing each word with deliberation. "But it’s not just about the divorce papers. It's about helping people through difficult transitions and moving forward."

"The irony isn't lost on me that the person currently handling them may have had a hand in making those papers necessary in the first place," Marco retorts.

"I can see how you'd think that, but—"

"But what?" he interrupts sharply. "What did I miss? How do your clients move forward when their pasts are dictated by broken promises and shattered dreams?"

"Are you suggesting I enable these divorces or something?" My voice cracks despite my best efforts to remain composed.

"No," he replies grimly, shaking his head slightly. "I'm trying to understand why someone who fights for second chances doesn’t take their own advice."

"That’s not fair," I protest. The warmth from the pasta dish in front of me offers little comfort now that something slow-burns beneath the surface between us like a simmering stew.

"Is it?" he challenges, his eyes searching mine with a penetrating intensity.

I look down at my untouched plate. "I'm trying to make amends." My voice barely audible over the hum of the restaurant background noise.

"And with whom?" Marco presses further, leaning away from me as if recoiling at my admission.

"With myself, too," I admit quietly.

A seconds stack up without words between us and it feels heavy, oppressive. The words left unsaid hang in the air like smoke, thick and bitter.

Marco reaches for his glass of water but doesn’t take a sip. Instead, he runs his fingers over the rim as if measuring out each one of our missed opportunities and unspoken apologies.

"How do you feel when people walk through your doors?" Marco finally asks, his voice steady yet laden with underlying emotion.

"They're seeking clarity," I respond, my chin lifting slightly in defiance. "And sometimes that means letting go of the past so they can create a new future."

"But at what cost?" he counters vehemently.

"At whatever price it takes for them to be happy and find peace." My voice wavers but holds steady under his unflinching gaze.

"Do you think their happiness is worth the pain they inflict on others in the process?"

"The decision isn't mine," I assert, my tone hardening. "It's theirs. And sometimes..."

"Sometimes what?" he urges, leaning forward as if searching for those unfinished words from deep within me.

"...sometimes letting go of toxic relationships and unhealthy dynamics leads to growth," I finish softly but resolutely, meeting his eyes with equal conviction.

Marco leans back in his chair then, crossing one arm over the other on top of the table. "I believe that."

"And yet here we are, testing boundaries and pushing limits." He grates out lowly.

"Neither do I," I shoot back hotly before draw in air slowly to quell my rising temper.

The waiter interrupts the silence by placing our orders on the table, saving me from answering further at this juncture. But I know this conversation is far from over. It’s only just begun.

As he sets down our plates, I take a bite of pasta—savoring its rich flavors in an attempt to anchor myself back into this world.

"Is that why you chose this again?" Marco asks, his gaze never leaving mine.

I swallow hard and nod, my eyes shifting away from him momentarily. "Maybe."

His hand reaches across the table, his fingers brushing mine ever so slightly.

I look down at my plate, my something slams behind my sternum with a mix of emotions.

The storm brewing between us still rages on unabated; our confrontation only just starting amidst the din of an otherwise tranquil restaurant.

scenes.location: Lena’s workspace within the Amalfi villa
scenes.content:
The storm rages as I leave the trattoria, my heart heavy with guilt and urgency. Fork hovering over untouched pasta, I push away from the table and stand abruptly. No point in lingering here anymore; everything between us has changed.

Stepping out into the rain-drenched streets of Positano, drops pelt against my skin like icy needles. The villa is nearby, but a sudden downpour forces me to take shelter in an alley until it passes. Each minute feels like another step further from resolving our issues.

By the time I reach the villa, the storm has lessened slightly. Pushing open the heavy wooden door, I enter and the scent of rain mixes with warmth. Stepping into my workspace within Marco’s Amalfi villa, a sanctuary filled with memories, my gaze lands on the file folder containing wedding documents—I shouldn’t have access to them. My my fingertips vibrate as they brush against it; I force myself not to open it.

Heading upstairs to the main office area, I pull out my phone and send a text: "Marco, can we talk now?" No response comes back as I wait anxiously before stepping inside. Marco sits at his desk surrounded by paperwork for the wedding arrangements. His shoulders tense when he sees me but don’t turn around yet.

“Marco,” I say quietly, trying not to startle him. He let the tension leak from my lungs and turns slowly in his chair without looking up first.

“I need an explanation,” he says firmly, voice crackling with tension. “Why were you handling divorce papers for my family? Did you know something I didn’t?”

His question hangs between us like a cold gust of wind, making the air chill despite being inside this warm space.

“I don't... I wasn’t aware,” I reply hesitantly, glancing away and back again as my mind races to clarify further but falters. “I swear I had no idea it was personal.”

Marco’s expression shifts slightly—maybe a flicker of something softer or more conflicted—but he doesn’t let that show for long as his guard returns swiftly.

“I need to know I can trust you,” he says firmly, his eyes hardening into ice. But there's an undercurrent in his tone, suggesting doubts running deeper than just this instant moment.

“What if I can’t tell you everything?” I respond carefully, trying to gauge his reaction as he meets my gaze again. The intensity in his eyes seems to waver but doesn’t fully dissipate.

Our fingers brush on the wedding documents on his desk. He tightens them around mine in an unspoken agreement.

“We do,” he says firmly, nodding slowly before standing up and turning towards me. Releasing our joined hands briefly, he runs a hand through his damp hair. “We need clarity.”

“Clarity,” I repeat softly, nodding back at him. “we both need it.”

As we remain standing there, the weight of unresolved issues still hanging heavily between us—there’s also an unspoken determination not to let this be the end. Not just yet.

“We’ll need to talk more,” he says finally, breaking the silence with a nod towards me and setting his phone down on the desk. “Tonight.”

“Tonight then,” I agree, my voice steady but carrying an undercurrent of uncertainty. For now, we can only proceed one step at a time—searching for answers amidst the storm, hoping that shared resolve might be enough to weather whatever comes next.

He nods and checks his phone quickly before looking back up at me with finality in his eyes. “Let’s meet here at eight.”

Pulling my hand free, I step back towards the door, leaving the office without another word. The weight of uncertainty presses down on me as I walk through the villa, each step echoing with the possibility of a breaking relationship.

Outside, by the file folder containing wedding documents, I pause, knowing it holds answers to questions Marco will ask tonight. But retrieving them now would only deepen his mistrust. I must wait until our meeting and hope that honesty can bridge the growing chasm between us.

scenes.content:
The cliff overlooking the Amalfi Coast is my sanctuary tonight, a place where thoughts swirl and emotions pour out like relentless waves crashing below me. Each rock beneath my feet holds weight; each step treads toward understanding, each pause an invitation to reckon with uncertainty. Leaning against the railing, saltwater scents whisper of distant storms yet unseen. The cliffs echo back the sound of my exhale, heavy with unresolved tension.

I close my eyes, allowing myself to fall into memories—moments replay in vivid flashes, each one a reminder of who I am now: a lawyer navigating not just cases but also personal boundaries that blur and shift. Abuela’s words ring softly in my mind, a gentle lullaby turning fierce with truth: "La vida es un juego de azar." Life is a game of chance, where every decision shapes the unpredictable path ahead. But here I am, caught between choices and consequences, trying to reconcile past actions that now feel like heavy chains anchoring me down.

Marco telling me about his brother’s death—stormy night in Positano transforming into a fragile bridge connecting us across years of silence. His strength, his vulnerability—all interwoven with moments when we stood together against the elements, both searching for solid ground amidst emotional tempests.

"Lena," Marco calls from below, voice steady but firm. "Can we—just, sit for a minute about your decision."

Pulling out my phone, notifications glow ominously like a mocking beacon calling but never reaching closer. With I can't hold them steady slightly, I type quick words of dismissal:

_Sorry, Marco. Just need some space._

Pressing send feels like sealing a fate that might break more than mend. Yet there is no other way forward; each step must be deliberate and defined.

Walking back toward the villa, wind picks up around me, carrying another reminder: _We’ll need to talk more._ His words linger long after his departure—promises and uncertainties entwined. But now isn’t the time for conversation; too much swirls inside my head, demanding space to sort through. Wind nips at exposed skin, sending goosebumps along my arms—a physical echo of emotional turmoil.

Ahead lies the villa, silhouetted against the deepening night sky, its lights flickering off one by one like unanswered questions. Inside, familiar environment comforts but challenges me. Corridor echoes with my footsteps; each room door offers a glimpse into another layer of unresolved emotions. I move toward my workspace, where everything began and continues to unfold.

Opening laptop, files quietly remind me that reality cannot be ignored. But focusing on work is impossible; mind keeps drifting back to the cliff’s edge, to every fragment since—our conversation, his concern, my withdrawal…

Gianna crosses her arms, I squint slightly. "You can’t keep pushing everyone away like this."

Her words cut through thoughts like a sharp knife, leaving me momentarily stunned. Kneeling down, I pause to breathe and look up at Gianna with resolve.

“I need to talk to Marco,” I say firmly, making up my mind. “Tonight.” The decision feels heavy but necessary—a step toward facing what lies ahead rather than running from it. Walking back out into night air, cool embrace carries a sense of clarity.

Moonlight casts long shadows across the courtyard as I enter the villa again. Soft glow from the kitchen offers a welcoming contrast to darkness outside. Gianna is there, waiting by the stove, stirring something in the pot. Night is quiet as I make my way through the villa to Marco’s room. Each step feels like weight lifted off shoulders with every decision toward clarity.

Outside, storm continues relentless progress—no matter how much one tries to avoid confronting fears, they will always find us eventually. When I reach his door, something hammers once then settles in chest. Knock softly and wait for him to answer.

“Lena?” His voice is low but steady as he opens the door.

“Yes,” I reply. “There's something I need to say.”

Room is dimly lit by moonlight filtering through sheer curtains. He steps back, inviting me inside. As I enter, warmth of his home envelops me, stark contrast to chill outside.

“Sit down,” he says gently, gesturing toward the couch. Nod, taking a seat as he sits beside me. Silence between us is palpable, charged with unspoken words and unresolved tension.

“I’m sorry for pushing you away earlier,” I begin, voice steady but filled with emotion. He turns to face me, eyes searching mine. “You don’t have to apologize. I understand.”

“No,” I interrupt softly, reaching out to take his hand. “I do need to explain myself.”

His grip tightens around fingers as he nods in understanding.

“I feel like we’re walking on thin ice,” I admit, looking down at our intertwined hands. “Every step forward feels precarious.”

He sighs deeply, gaze turning inward before meeting mine again. “It’s okay to be scared, Lena. But running away won’t solve anything.”

Nodding, feeling the deep sense of truth in his words, I look back up at him.

“Tonight,” he says firmly, squeezing my hand one last time before releasing it. His eyes hold a mix of hope and worry as he looks into mine. “We’ll talk more tonight.”

With that, both rise to leave for bed, each carrying a newfound sense of determination. As I turn off his bedside light and walk back out into silent villa, there is a sense of peace knowing tomorrow we will start anew—with both questions and answers swirling around us.

Moonlight bathes the courtyard in silver, casting long shadows that dance with the wind. Each step toward my room feels like another decision made—decisions that shape not just today but future days to come. At the threshold of my door, I pause, turning back one last time to look at Marco’s closed door across the courtyard.

His silhouette is faint through his window as he stands by his own doorway, looking out into the night. A single tear rolls down my cheek unnoticed, a silent promise carried on the wind between us.

Tomorrow will hold answers—or new questions.

scenes.location: Secluded beach area north of Amalfi
scenes.content:
Rain pelts against my back as I sprint through the dark alleys of Amalfi's stormy night, my feet splashing in puddles. My blood rushes to my ears not just from the exertion but also from a sense of urgency that gnaws at me—the need to confront Marco about those wedding documents he’s been withholding from me.

Sinking into a chair at my workspace inside the Amalfi villa, I stare out at the stormy sea beyond the window. Silence fills the room except for the distant rumble of thunder. My mind races with conflicting thoughts and unresolved tensions from Marco’s revelation about the wedding documents.

I sigh heavily and stand, heading out into the rain-soaked garden. Trees sway ominously in the wind, their leaves rustling with each gust. Along the path leading to the secluded beach north of Amalfi, the rhythmic sound of raindrops merges with my footsteps. The stormy waves crash against rugged cliffs as I reach a small cove bordered by boulders and sparse vegetation. The coastline is desolate, save for a lone figure standing amidst the rocks.

My heart flutters at the sight of him; he turns to face me, eyes scanning the shore before landing on mine.

“Thought you’d find your way here,” Marco says gruffly, not moving from his spot by the water’s edge. His voice is soft but carries in the wind.

"You should've told me sooner about those documents," I snap, my voice sharp as a legal brief. "It seems like everywhere I go, you're somehow there too."

I pause and start walking toward him until we stand shoulder-to-shoulder. The salt air clings to our skin as waves break around us.

Marco chuckles softly, glancing at me out the corner of his eye. “This place… it’s like our own little storm front.” He steps closer and offers an arm to shield us from the rain as we walk along the shoreline. The sand beneath my feet is cold and wet, each step leaving a mark in its wake.

“We have a lot to sort through,” he says quietly. “The documents, our feelings—everything.”

Marco’s hand brushes against mine; I feel warmth spreading through me despite the stormy weather. We stop near a large boulder jutting out from the rocky beach, its rugged surface offering respite from the onslaught of water.

"Gianna won't like this," I say firmly, meeting his gaze. "She’ll see us together and think we’re plotting against her."

“So, what now?” More to myself than him, though my eyes meet his once again. The intensity in his gaze sends a shiver running through me—from both fear and longing.

“We keep moving forward,” he says, meeting my glance without breaking contact. “Tonight, we’ll figure everything out.”

My heart skips several beats at those words. Amidst nature’s fury, something shifts between us—promises made under the threat of storm clouds feel as real as ever before.

We remain silent for a long while longer, simply standing there together against the pounding rain and crashing waves. Once the silence ends, it will usher forth another chapter filled with questions yet unanswered—and answers ready to be found, no matter how daunting that might seem.

"Tonight, we figure out our next move," he says, his voice steady but urgent.

“Tonight,” I repeat quietly, letting myself believe maybe this fragile peace could turn into something more solid if we both commit ourselves wholeheartedly. As the rain continues its relentless patter around us, all I can do is hope for a chance at redemption—and perhaps even healing—in whatever challenges lie ahead.

Marco reaches out and tucks a strand of wet hair behind my ear; his fingers linger on my cheek before he withdraws them. “Tonight,” he says again, this time with more conviction. His touch sends a jolt through me, igniting a fire that threatens to consume all the unresolved tension between us.

“Tonight,” I echo, nodding resolutely. The decision is made.

The storm continues unabated, its fury an apt metaphor for the tempest inside my heart. But tonight, we stand together, ready to face our demons and navigate the uncharted waters ahead.

scenes.location: Lemon grove near the Amalfi coast
scenes.content:
The lemon grove near Amalfi’s coast is a quiet sanctuary where light filters through leaves and casts golden speckles on the ground. I wander along the narrow paths, inhaling the sweet scent of citrus blossoms mixed with sea air. It’s a stark contrast from yesterday’s stormy cliff or the secluded beach shrouded in rain. Today offers an uneasy respite.

At the base of a lemon tree, I stop and pick one, biting into its zestful flesh. The sharp tang is a reminder of reality—a fresh start mixed with lingering doubts. Reality clings to every bite.

Marco approaches silently, his presence unmistakable in this serene setting. His eyes hold traces of the same contemplation that lingers in mine.

"You always find your way back here, don’t you?" Marco’s voice held a hint of amusement as he leaned against the trunk of a lemon tree.

“Good morning,” I say quietly, but even that simple greeting carries weight. A nod to acknowledge his presence without overthinking it.

“What are you thinking?” He asks softly, pulling up alongside me.

“I’m just trying to make sense of everything,” I reply, tossing another lemon between my hands. “It feels like every step forward is two steps back.”

“Does it have to be that way?”

I pause, considering his question. His words carry the warmth and sincerity he tries so hard to convey, but they also stir up a tangle of emotions within me.

“Do you believe in second chances?” I counter, meeting his gaze head-on without flinching. “Because sometimes it feels like we’ve run out of them.”

“Second chances are all about redemption,” Marco says, leaning against the trunk of the tree, drawing us closer together. His tone is gentle yet firm, as if he’s laying down stakes.

“I’m not sure if I believe in that anymore.” My fingers fidget with the stem of a lemon. “Or maybe I’m just scared to try.”

“What are you scared of?” He regards me with a look both understanding and pained.

“Scared of failing again,” I admit after a moment’s hesitation, the words feeling heavy and hard to utter aloud. “But also scared of succeeding when everything around us says it shouldn’t work.” My fingers fidget with the stem of a lemon as his hand reaches out for mine.

“What you do for a living doesn’t define who you are,” he says softly, his eyes softening as he speaks. His thumb brushes over my knuckles in a gentle gesture that grounds me to the present moment. “It’s about choices we make every day.”

“You keep mentioning second chances.” I choose my words carefully. “But what if they aren’t enough?”

“What can we do then?” He asks directly, without hiding behind his usual humor or deflection tactics when things get tough.

I take another deep breath, the citric scent filling my lungs. "We can only hope." The words hang between us as another moment of silence passes.

“Hope and act,” Marco corrects me gently. His hand moves along the curve of my cheek, his thumb brushing over my earlobe—a gesture so familiar yet loaded with newfound meaning right now.

"Promise me you’ll take this chance," he whispers into my ear, breath warm against my skin.

I lean back, meeting his eyes through a curtain of hair. “It’s not just about taking chances—that part is easy.” My fingers fidget nervously at the stem of a lemon. “It’s making them last.”

“I know,” Marco says solemnly. His hand moves to the small of my back, guiding me against the trunk of the lemon tree behind me.

“Promise me you’ll be honest with me from now on.” I glance around us quickly at this grove filled with lemon trees. The golden hues of the morning light through leaves make everything seem possible but also daunting. “It’s not just about taking chances—that part is easy.”

“What are you ready to give up for that honesty?” he asks intently, his eyes searching mine.

I look back up into his eyes. “Yes,” I say finally. “But it won’t be easy.”

“We’ve never said anything would be.” He tucks a strand of hair behind my ear before dropping another kiss onto my forehead—a simple gesture that speaks volumes about hope and resilience. "And you know what?" Marco says with determination, pulling me closer once more but this time without moving his hand from where it rests lightly on the curve of my waist. "This—whatever we have—is worth fighting for."

His words resonate deeply within me as I hold onto him tightly, feeling a rare sense of vulnerability washing over me.

As we stand there beneath the lemon trees bathed in golden light, every glance and touch carries significance now. Each moment feels precious yet fraught with future uncertainty. But for a brief instant here among citrus blossoms and quiet groves, hope takes hold once more.

scenes.location: Wedding setup area in Amalfi villa gardens
scenes.content:
Marco’s words hung like a breath of fresh air in the lemon grove’s heavy stillness. Our hands had intertwined without planning, and now we stood beneath the golden light filtering through thick leaves, each step cautious yet deliberate, carrying forward the weight we’d only just begun to acknowledge.

I could feel his gaze lingering on me, tracing the line of my jaw before settling further down. Nerves fluttered in my stomach—a mix of old familiar fear and a newfound hope that felt almost painful. “We should head back,” I announced more firmly than I intended, pulling us from our reverie. The sun was low in the horizon, painting everything in soft oranges and pinks.

“Of course,” he agreed, but there was hesitation in his voice as he tugged at my hand, guiding me forward instead of breaking away. He didn’t need to say it aloud; I already knew what this meant. We were heading back towards the villa, towards our roles as planners under scrutiny—not just for this wedding, but for each other.

As we walked through winding paths lined with lemon trees, their bittersweet scent mingling with sea breezes, every step felt like a test. Would our fragile truce withstand another day? Another challenge?

“What’s on your mind?” he asked softly as we turned a corner and faced the villa gardens sprawling before us. His tone was softer than usual, more curious without the usual mask of charm or deflection.

I paused momentarily, studying his face—his eyes darkened with an intensity that went beyond mere intrigue. “Just wondering if there’s anything left between us,” I admitted bluntly. The words hovered out loud, sharp and clear against the quiet air. It was a question as much as it was a statement, one that hung unspoken for most of our time here.

He stopped too, his grip on my hand tightening slightly, but he didn’t turn to face me yet. “What do you want there to be left?” His voice was steady, probing rather than defensive.

I sighed deeply then, more tired than I cared to admit. The question felt like a trap and a lifeline all at once. What did I want? More importantly, what could we possibly hope for after everything that had happened?

“I don’t know,” I confessed honestly, finally turning towards him now under the lemon trees’ shade. “But if there is something left to salvage…” My voice faltered slightly before finding its strength again, “…I think we owe it to ourselves to try.”

His gaze met mine then with a rare vulnerability, as though our roles were somehow reversed—not just planner to client but two people grappling for connection amidst chaos. He nodded slowly, his lips quirking into an understanding smile. “Agreed.”

He stepped closer and the familiar warmth of his touch against my skin returned, sending shivers down my spine. Our bodies almost touched, yet the space between us felt charged with unspoken words.

“Looks like today won’t be easy,” Marco noted as we stepped into the bustling scene, his voice low yet clear above the hum of activity. A couple argued about seating arrangements near us; I could see shadows passing across their faces. Their concerns mirrored my own in many ways.

Nodding, I swallowed hard against rising anxiety. This wasn’t going to be just another day on set or a routine planning session—it was a collision course with everything we’d come to understand and fear about each other since reuniting here by the Amalfi coast. And though our hands were intertwined again, that alone didn not guarantee anything.

“Keep your gloves on for now,” I advised softly as we began navigating through the chaos towards where guests would gather soon. “We need to keep a clear head and make sure everyone else’s day isn’t ruined by our own hang-ups.”

He glanced at me sharply then, a spark of understanding in his eyes that cut right through my defensive walls. It reminded me how much he cared beneath all the charm—and it hurt because I still wasn’t entirely sure what caring really meant anymore.

With that thought nagging at me, we dove headfirst into our responsibilities—the first true test of whether we could be more than just planners for this wedding and its aftermath. As we moved through the crowd, coordinating last-minute details, every moment felt charged with possibility—or potential disaster.

“We’ve got this,” Marco said quietly near my ear as a bridesmaid approached us frantic about misplaced invitations. “What’s next?” he asked me, his eyes scanning the scene for another issue needing our attention.

I nodded resolutely, returning a reassuring smile to her worried face despite my doubts. We did have this—more or less—but the real question was how much of it would carry over into our own lives outside these manicured gardens and scheduled events.

The day pressed forward relentlessly from there—an endless cycle of adjustments, compromises, and occasional flashpoints with each other where we struggled not to revert back to old patterns. Yet through it all, despite or because of the chaos swirling around us, something shifted quietly between us; a silent agreement that perhaps sometimes the mess is necessary before clarity can return.

As night fell slowly over Amalfi and the final guests made their way into the reception tent, our hands remained entwined tightly as we stood side by side overseeing it all. In this moment at least, among scattered flowers and dimming lights of lanterns, I felt a glimmering thread of hope rekindled—hope that whatever came next could be faced together.

But as we turned to head inside the tent for our final checklist before guests arrived in full force, his eyes caught mine one last time. They held a question I couldn’t answer yet—a promise I wasn’t sure was ready to keep.

scenes.content:
I grip the stone railing, my knuckles white as I stare out at the darkening horizon. The storm is coming, and so are the thoughts it carries. A soft knock startles me from my reverie. “Come,” I call without turning, knowing who’s there.

Marco steps into the space with a deliberate grace that feels like an unspoken challenge. He pauses near the door, his gaze scanning the room before settling on me. The scent of rain on concrete trails behind him, marking his presence even before I see him standing near the edge, looking out towards the dark expanse of the coast.

I turn fully now to face him, trying not to let the subtle shifts in our dynamic show too much. “Checking what?” My tone is neutral despite how firmly my feet are rooted in place.

He hesitates a moment before answering, his gaze flicking back towards me. “The storm’s rolling in,” he says finally, gesturing vaguely beyond the balcony railings to where black clouds gather on the horizon. “I thought you might want an umbrella.”

“No thanks.” I wave off his offer with one hand while folding my arms over my chest. The air is cool against my skin tonight, carrying a chill that nips at exposed areas.

Our eyes meet across inches of open space where words cannot bridge yet still carry meaning. For a moment, I’m struck by how familiar these interactions have become—and how strange they remain at once. Each exchange feels like a delicate dance around unspoken truths waiting to be named but not quite ready for voice just yet.

Marco breaks the gaze first this time, his eyes scanning back out over the dark horizon now rather than settling on me again right away. “You know,” he says softly, turning slightly towards me, “I don’t think I’ve ever seen something shift so quickly between us.” His tone is contemplative more than accusatory; still, it feels bracing to hear aloud.

“Agreed,” I respond carefully. “A lot can happen in three years.”

He nods slowly but doesn’t turn back towards me yet, his expression unreadable from this distance. Instead, he steps closer now until there’s only the stone ledge between us again—enough space left that we aren't quite touching but also too close to ignore.

“The thing is,” he continues after another pause long enough for tension to build up once more in my chest, “it feels different tonight.” There’s a soft emphasis on those last words which makes them feel pointed even if nothing else changes outwardly in his demeanor. It’s the kind of observation that leaves plenty open-ended but also firmly planted.

I watch him out of the corner of my eyes while pretending to study some far-off point beyond the edge instead. “Different how?” My voice doesn’t betray me entirely—I hope—but I can feel the edges of my defenses flinch just slightly with those three little words alone.

Marco turns back fully now, his gaze finding mine again; it’s a direct look this time rather than another half-measure meant to hedge things. His chin lifts fractionally before he speaks directly into the gap separating us without wavering now. “Tonight...” He trails off deliberately for effect before finishing softly but firmly, “tonight feels real.”

Real enough that when his hand finally brushes against mine where it rests along the railing, a spark of awareness shoots through both of us almost like an electric current. My lungs stall in my throat momentarily as I sense him drawing closer rather than pulling back now.

We stand there facing each other under darkening skies for long moments more; every silence between us speaks volumes about what remains unsaid yet understood perfectly well anyway. Finally, with something sharp and clear settling finally into his eyes again after this momentary exchange of looks and touch, he steps back just a little bit further instead—enough to create some space but not too much so we still feel each other’s presence strongly.

“Tonight might be real,” Marco agrees quietly before turning fully away now towards the door without another word beyond that simple confirmation. “But tomorrow...that one remains to be seen.”

With those final words hanging heavy between us, he retreats back through the open doorway into whatever waits inside the villa while leaving me behind on this quiet rooftop with more questions than answers tonight. The storm clouds gather closer still as I watch him go, wondering what storms of my own are on the horizon now that feel equally inevitable no matter how much we try to deny their approach first.

The night air carries his departing scent away into the distance along with every word left unspoken now but understood all too clearly anyway.

The rain started just before dawn, droplets clinging to my eyelashes and pooling on the rooftop tiles. I stepped inside with a soft click of the sliding glass door behind me. My goal was clear: maintain a professional facade despite the mutual attraction Marco and I still felt for each other.

Silence filled the villa except for distant thunder rumbles as I made my way down to the ground floor, thinking about Marco's retreating form and the weight in his eyes.

In the dining room, Sofia bustled with cups of coffee for Gianna’s early morning meeting. She paused when she saw me but resumed her pace without a word.

“Morning, Lena,” Gianna called out from a side room. I replied crisply, “Good morning.”

The sudden change in atmosphere threw me off balance as I entered the cozy nook where pastries and fruits waited.

“There’s much to go over regarding guest accommodations and vendor setup.” Her pragmatic demeanor unsettled me.

Marco walked in then, his hair slightly damp from another quick trip outside. He paused at the door, glancing between Gianna and me before stepping fully into the room.

“Good morning,” he said simply, not breaking eye contact with my grandmother but clearly aware of my presence too.

Gianna raised an eyebrow as if gauging his arrival, then nodded towards a chair by the table. “We need to finalize certain arrangements regarding your side of wedding planning.”

A knot tightened in my stomach at her words—and how they hung between us, another layer added on top of all that was already there.

Marco took his seat with an air of resignation. Legal jargon filled the room’s atmosphere with a sense of urgency despite the early hour.

I caught Marco's eye briefly as numbers were tossed around; there was no mistaking the shared strain that flashed between us. I looked away quickly, focusing instead on trying to parse through assigned responsibilities.

“Sofia,” Gianna said approvingly before another sharp look at Marco, “We’ll need to make sure everything goes smoothly for guests.”

Marco leaned forward slightly as Sofia cheerfully broke some of the tension with her enthusiasm. Her plans seemed different somehow when he listened intently.

Sofia glanced over at me, my eyes twinkling with mischief. “Lena, you should definitely come along for the tour.”

“I would love to go,” I agreed readily enough.

Despite everything swirling around us now, my thoughts kept returning to that wine tasting tour somehow.

As midmorning approached and the meeting finally wound down thanks largely to Gianna’s efficiency, I lingered behind for just another few minutes while everyone else scattered off towards their respective tasks.

“Are you sure going on the vineyard tour is okay?” I asked softly as Marco started packing up his side of things from one of the tables. He looked up then paused slightly before responding with a slow nod.

“Yes,” he replied, voice warm and steady despite everything swirling beneath it still too unsettled for comfort yet either way. “It’s all part of making sure everything goes well.”

His eyes met mine again briefly but this time held longer than before, as if we were finding each other all over again in this quiet space between us.

“Thank you,” I replied quietly back to him then turned away just a moment too late noticing how his gaze followed me. My hands began fidgeting with the straps on my bag.

Recalling the feel of those same fingers guiding papers through legal proceedings before we had even known each other as anything more than clients, all that history lay heavily now between us—the unspoken knowledge of each other’s secrets intertwined with newly revealed depths of shared pain.

The next time we spoke would be different somehow; a shift already felt in the way our eyes held each other then let go again too soon into this ongoing dance. And with those final thoughts lingering as palpably as ever, I left for my own tasks knowing only what was to come later today—more than just another day of preparations but another chance at untangling all that lay between us.

Stepping outside into the cool morning air where Marco already stood waiting quietly against the stone wall, the space around us hummed with a different kind of electricity now as he finally spoke first again:

“The vineyard tour can be challenging,” his words were low and careful but also oddly reassuring despite any lingering uncertainties. He ran a hand through his damp hair.

“And there’s always a chance for some unexpected discoveries too,” I replied, my gaze steady on him in turn. My fingers tightened around the strap of my bag.

A beat passed between us before he nodded ever so slightly as if agreeing with more than just the literal meaning of those words.

With that tacit understanding shared at last, we set off together down the path towards our next encounter—one destined to reveal still more beneath all that had already unfolded between us.
