scenes.content:
Stepping out onto the balcony, I pause at the edge where moonlight meets the silhouette of the Amalfi coastline. The night air is crisp and carries a hint of salt from the nearby sea. Goosebumps prickle my skin as my hand traces the cold railing. A shiver runs through me—more than just from the chill.

Marco stands beside me, his presence more than a shadow in this moonlit moment. “Can we—just, sit for a minute,” he says softly, turning towards me with an intensity that speaks louder than words. I nod, knowing there’s no way around this conversation tonight. Every breeze whispers reminders of our complex history.

“Let’s go inside,” I suggest after a beat, my voice sharp and steady despite the undercurrents swirling beneath the surface. “It’s late.” Before we can move back towards the hotel room’s warmth, his hand reaches out to grasp mine—a gesture that catches me off guard more than it should after all these years.

“Lena,” he begins hesitantly, searching for the right words amid a storm of emotions. His grip is firm but not intrusive, grounding my feet where they stand and forcing me to look at him squarely in the eye. I pull back gently, uncurling our intertwined fingers. The space between us widens slightly, though it doesn’t lessen the weight that’s always been there since he found out about my role in his family's divorce proceedings.

“It isn't,” I agree, letting my eyes drift down to the dark expanse below before meeting his gaze once more. We both know we’re walking on thin ice here—with every word and gesture threatening to send us crashing into an uncertain future. Yet there’s a strange sense of inevitability in this moment—that whatever unfolds between us can’t be avoided anymore than the tides that shape these cliffs.

When I look back up, Marco’s face is tight with something half-concerned, half-resolute as if he’s bracing himself for what lies ahead. “I want to understand,” he says finally, his voice low but clear. It feels like a confession, an admission of need rather than confrontation. And so, I take a breath—a deep inhale that tries to steady my nerves—and nod again.

“I know,” I whisper in return, each syllable carrying its own weight within this silent exchange. There's an acknowledgment in every line of his body now, a recognition that we’re standing at a crossroads where all bets are off and the future hinges on what happens next. My heart begins to race as he steps closer again, but not with fear or trepidation this time—just the undeniable force of us coming to terms with everything.

The balcony door creaks softly behind me as I turn back towards warmth, but my focus remains locked onto Marco’s face, watching for any hint of what might come. When he doesn’t speak again right away, only follows silently until we’re both inside once more, the tension between us almost palpable in the quiet.

The night is young and full of possibilities that neither of us can yet fully grasp—but somehow it feels like nothing else matters except this moment and whatever paths our conversation might set forth. Taking a step into the room now lit only by a dim lamp, I feel the edges of my resolve sharpening. There are no more walls left to hide behind tonight; just two people who’ve been circling each other’s orbits for far too long finally acknowledging the pull between them.

As he moves past me towards one of the sitting areas, I turn and head in the opposite direction—towards a chair by the window where the moonlight is strongest. Setting myself down with a slight sigh, my mind begins to race—not inwardly but outwardly now focused on what needs to be said. The seconds stack up without words awkwardly for a moment or two before he joins me, sitting across from my chosen seat and leaning forward slightly as if readying himself for whatever might come next.

“Tell me how you see us,” he prompts quietly after another pause too long to ignore. His eyes are probing but not accusing, seeking clarity rather than confrontation. It feels like a request tinged with an underlying urgency, as if both of us recognize that any longer delay could push this conversation—and possibly our relationship—into uncharted territory.

“Honestly?” I ask back softly, my thoughts swirling but starting to coalesce into some semblance of order. “I see us...as complicated,” I finish truthfully, meeting his gaze head-on without flinching. The corners of his mouth twitch slightly—a mix of recognition and reluctant acceptance as if he’s been expecting this answer all along.

“We both know that complications aren’t always bad,” Marco counters in a measured tone, leaning back now so we’re eye level once more. “We just need to figure out how those complexities fit together.” His words hang between us like an unspoken truth, a challenge and a plea wrapped into one sentence. It’s clear that he wants more than mere acknowledgment of the difficulties—what he desires is the courage to face them head-on.

A deep breath fills my lungs as I contemplate his response. “Yes,” I affirm quietly but resolutely, letting out another exhale as some of the tension eases from within me at finally admitting this much out loud. The decision isn’t about dismissing our problems but rather embracing them with a will to find solutions where before there were only doubts.

“I want that too,” I say firmly now, making sure my voice carries conviction and purpose. “But it means being honest with ourselves—not just each other.” I pause briefly before adding, “No more hiding behind what’s easy or convenient.”

A flicker of something—maybe relief, maybe resolve—passes over his features at these words. For a moment, we simply sit there mirroring each other in the soft glow from outside, our gazes locked together like they any sense of separation from that first balcony conversation.

“You’re right,” Marco agrees after another moment’s thought, “It isn’t about avoiding what comes next—it’s knowing why it came to be.” His eyes soften slightly now, a hint of vulnerability creeping into their depths as if allowing himself to feel fully in this moment rather than holding back out of habit or fear. “And understanding where we’re headed.”

There's an unspoken acknowledgment that whatever lies ahead won't be easy but there’s also a growing awareness of mutual trust and respect building between us. This conversation, these words being exchanged, are laying the groundwork for moving forward despite—and perhaps because—of our past.

“Okay,” I nod quietly in agreement as both acceptance and anticipation fill my chest. “Then let's begin by understanding one another better.” And with those last few words hanging between us like a promise unspoken yet understood completely, I feel that initial push towards clarity transforming into the first tentative steps of rebuilding what might be.

Marco’s gaze remains steady on mine for several more seconds before finally breaking contact in favor of turning his focus away from me—to look out the window instead. The moonlight catches the subtle creases around his eyes, highlighting years of experience, resilience, and now...hope maybe?

Taking this as our cue to shift gears, I take another deep breath in preparation for what lies ahead—both inside this room and beyond into an uncertain future together.

“We have a lot of ground to cover,” he says softly once more, breaking the spell with words that feel like stepping stones. “But we can tackle it piece by piece if need be.”

I nod again as my chest feels like a drum not just from anxiety but also excitement at the prospect of working through issues head-on rather than running away from them.

“Piece by piece,” I echo softly, knowing this is only the beginning.

The night air outside feels cooler now, the stars twinkling above like tiny promises. I lean back into the chair, feeling a mix of emotions swirl inside me—hope, fear, determination. This is just the start, but it’s a start nonetheless. The past can’t be erased, but maybe together we can shape a future that neither of us dared to dream possible before.

The room seems to grow quieter around us as the weight of what we’ve agreed to settles in. But there’s also an undercurrent of something new—something hopeful and fragile, like the first tentative rays of dawn breaking through the night sky.

With a final glance at Marco, who still looks out the window lost in his thoughts, I feel my resolve solidify further. This is our chance to build something real—something that’s worth fighting for. And as much as it scares me, there’s also an undeniable excitement at the prospect of facing this journey together.

The night feels like a prelude to what’s to come—a beginning rather than an end. We’ve taken the first steps towards understanding and confronting our past, but now we’re poised to move forward with purpose and intention. The future is uncertain, but for the first time in a long while, I feel ready to embrace it.

Piece by piece, one conversation at a time, we’ll build something that’s ours—a relationship worth fighting for, despite all its complexities and challenges.

The night is young, and so are we—in this moment, everything feels possible.

scenes.content:
Marco tugs on my hand, pulling me out onto the hotel balcony. The cool Amalfi breeze carries the scent of grapefruit and sea salt, mingling with hints of distant fireworks celebrating some local festival. We stand in quiet communion for a moment before I break the silence.

"I've been meaning to ask," I start, my voice steady despite the thoughts swirling within me. "What exactly happened between you and Sofia when we last worked together?"

His shoulders tense momentarily as he takes a deep breath. He shifts his weight slightly, leaning against the railing for support.

"It was nothing serious," Marco replies quickly, but his tone lacks conviction.

"Right." I turn to face him fully, folding my arms across my chest. "Nothing serious is the default cover for everything from minor crushes to full-blown heartbreak."

He meets my gaze steadily, searching for something in my eyes before sighing and rubbing his jawline thoughtfully.

"You're right," he says softly.

"We’re here now," I assert firmly, meeting his eyes straight on to reinforce my point. "And we're not just co-workers anymore."

"I know." His grip tightens slightly around the railing as if seeking reassurance from its solidity. "It's complicated."

"Isn’t it always?" My voice carries a sharp edge.

He chuckles softly, though there’s no mirth behind it—the sound echoes between us like an acknowledgment of shared pain and uncertainty. The night seems to blur into focus again as if every detail around us is conspiring to remind me why this moment is so crucial.

"Let's head over to that wine tasting session," Marco suggests abruptly, moving away from the balcony edge towards the door.

"What about your… connection with Sofia?" I push back, feeling compelled to press further as we walk inside. "Don’t you think it’ll be awkward?"

He shakes his head firmly.“No.” His voice is resolute. “We worked through our issues during that last project. Besides,” he adds with a hint of amusement in his eyes, “Sofia’s long moved on.”

My mouth opens to respond but then closes again; I find myself at a loss for words despite my usual sharp tongue. Instead, we leave the hotel room and make our way down to the wine tasting venue in silence.

Amalfi nights are alive with chatter and laughter spilling out from every corner of the town streets below us. The glow of lanterns casts an ethereal light on the winding pathways leading up to the historic winery where dozens have gathered for tonight’s event. As we approach, people turn to watch our arrival, but I barely notice them.

Inside, the air is thick with anticipation and the rich aroma of decanting wine barrels lining one wall of the rustic hall. We slide into a corner booth near an open window offering breathtaking views of the coastline illuminated by moonlight. The moment we sit down, someone places two glasses in front of us before swiftly moving away to tend to other guests.

"Here's to new beginnings," Marco says without looking at me, raising his glass towards the landscape beyond our window frame.

I lift my own glass hesitantly and clink it against his. "New beginnings," I echo softly, my gaze following his as he looks out over the view.

Something about the way he regards this moment with such quiet determination tugs at a part of my heart that's been wary and guarded for far too long. The weight of all those unresolved emotions—our shared past, current uncertainties, professional obligations—are all present in his gaze as clearly as they are mine.

"I’m glad you came," Marco says quietly after a moment, setting his glass down on the table with deliberate care.

"Me too." I rest my fingers lightly overtop my own half-empty wineglass. "Marco… what do we do now?"

He draws in a deep breath and turns to face me fully once more.“We navigate it together,” he replies firmly. “But first, can you promise me something?”

My brow furrows slightly but I wait for him to continue.

“Tonight... let’s just be two people enjoying the night out here in Amalfi,” Marco pleads earnestly, his eyes reflecting the moonlit water outside as if searching for a shared truth there. “No past regrets or future fears.”

I hesitate only briefly before nodding.“Deal.” My voice sounds lighter than I feel.

He smiles at me warmly then leans forward to collect another glass of wine from passing servers. As I take mine gratefully, our fingers brush against each other’s rims. Heat spikes through me unexpectedly at the contact—undeniable proof that despite everything, there's still chemistry between us after all these years.

“So,” he says, drawing my attention back.“Tell me about your memories of Amalfi—what brings you here?”

I take a sip from my glass as I ponder his question. “Every summer as a kid, Abuela would regale us with stories of her travels to places like this—the vibrant markets, the colorful villages nestled amongst vineyards.” A wistful smile plays at the corners of my lips.

“And now you get to experience it,” Marco prompts gently.

“Exactly,” I agree softly. “It’s more than just a romantic getaway for me though; there are personal connections and memories tied up in each corner.”

He nods thoughtfully, eyes never leaving mine.“And what about your professional life back home? That must weigh on you too?”

I sigh deeply but manage to shake my head slightly.“You know,” I confess lowly, “sometimes it feels like every case I handle is one less chance for real human connection. But then there’s moments like tonight…”

“Tonight shows there are always going to be more chances,” Marco interjects softly.

“And that's a risk worth taking," I finish quietly.

We fall into contemplative silence once more, the buzz of celebration outside our intimate corner offering only soft background noise to fill the space where words leave off. For just this moment, tension eases around us and reality blurs into something softer and less defined.

Marco reaches out again, placing a hand over mine gently. "So let's promise each other," he murmurs warmly, fingers interlocking with mine briefly before releasing, "that no matter what happens next, we'll take these chances. Because this"—he gestures expansively towards the window to show everything beyond—“is worth fighting for.”

I meet his eyes steadfastly.“We navigate it together.” My voice sounds just as resolute.

In his gaze now, I see the man who once was and always will be more than a colleague or past flame—he is someone with whom future possibilities feel far less daunting. Yet despite this newfound clarity, uncertainties still linger beneath the surface of our connection like an undercurrent waiting to pull us back into deeper water where everything may not yet be as clear cut.

But for tonight—or however long we can hold onto these moments—there’s just us and a glass full of wine brimming with potential. As I look at Marco, I understand that the risk is worth it: every brush of his fingers against mine, every shared moment here in Amalfi—the stakes are high but so is the reward.

The room around us fades into background noise as he leans closer, his eyes never wavering from mine. The distance between us narrows with each passing breath until only a whisper separates our lips. I feel my ribcage vibrates in my chest and just when it seems like we're about to close the gap—

A sudden burst of music from outside snaps us back into reality. We freeze for a moment, eyes locked as if the rest of the world has stopped turning.

The night air is filled with laughter and joy, reminding me that while this moment feels intimate and charged with possibility, it’s also fleeting.

And so, we remain suspended in a quiet tension, both aware that tonight isn’t just about wine or Amalfi—it’s about us.

I flinch back as a sudden burst of thunder rips through the room, its deafening crack echoing in my ears long after it’s ended. My chest feels like a drum against my ribcage as I clutch the door handle, trying to gather enough courage to push inside.

Everything in me pauses, I push the hotel room door open with a subtle click and slip inside. The storm outside pounds against the windows like an angry fist, but here in this sanctuary of dim lighting and soft bedding, it’s quiet and sheltered. Marco stands by the window, his back to me, staring out at the tumultuous sea beyond.

“Marco,” I call softly, not wanting to startle him with my sudden presence.

He turns slowly, meeting my eyes. There’s a depth in those brown irises that reaches far into the past, where memories of loss and pain are buried under layers of resilience.

“I need to tell you something,” he starts, his voice barely more than a whisper in this quiet space. “It’s about Paolo.”

Paolo, Marco’s beloved younger brother whose memory still haunts every step he takes. The room seems smaller now as I listen to him recount what happened that night.

“Okay,” I reply gently, nodding to encourage him further.

He moves closer now, his steps slow and deliberate as if wary of triggering some internal alarm. “It was raining that night too…” He runs a hand through his hair, an unconscious gesture of nervousness or perhaps self-soothing. It’s a familiar movement that I recognize from our shared past—always present whenever he's grappling with something intensely personal.

Sitting beside him on the edge of the bed, I offer what little comfort I can without intruding on his space. “Tell me more,” I urge softly, my voice steady and supportive even though my percussion against my ribs inside my chest.

“Paolo’s death was a turning point for Marco,” I think to myself, knowing it sent ripples of regret and guilt that still echo between us now.

“I left him alone and then when I got home…” A shuddering breath escapes him, breaking through his composed exterior. “He wasn’t there.”

My throat clicksening against the lump of sadness forming in my throat. We’ve come full circle from where we started three years ago; there’s no denying how deeply connected our stories have become despite—or perhaps because—of that initial pain.

“Marco,” I say again, reaching a hand towards his shoulder without touching. “You can’t blame yourself for what happened.”

His eyes meet mine then, filled with a vulnerability that’s rare and potent. “But it feels like I let him down in the most basic way possible.” His voice quivers slightly before he continues. “And seeing you again… Lena, it’s made me confront so much.”

“And now,” I prompt gently, touching lightly on the new thread entwining us, “we’re doing what we can to make things right.”

Marco turns back towards me then, a flicker of hope lighting his eyes despite everything else that shadows them. Slowly but surely, he begins sharing how our current partnership isn’t just professional anymore—it’s reparative too.

“I didn’t expect to find this again,” he admits truthfully, his gaze softening as if seeing me anew through all these intervening years. “But here we are, facing so many of those old struggles together.”

I offer him a small smile, reflecting on how far both of us have come—and yet how much further we might travel.

“And that’s what matters,” I affirm quietly. “We’re here now—this is our chance to heal some of the wounds between us.”

His fingers brush against mine almost instinctively in response, sending another jolt through me despite knowing it shouldn’t stir up such reactions anymore. It’s a brief touch but carries significant weight given everything else happening around it.

But as quickly as that spark ignites, Marco pulls back—reality settling over him once more with sobering force.

“I still have questions though,” he murmurs honestly, breaking the momentary connection. “About you… and what you do.”

A shiver runs down my spine at those unspoken implications lurking beneath his words.

“And I will answer them,” I pledge resolutely, steeling myself for whatever consequences might follow.

I shift closer to Marco once more, intending to address the elephant in the room head-on rather than let it overshadow everything else we’ve accomplished here together.

“Tell me what you need to know,” I urge him softly. “We’ll face this challenge as well.”

He nods slowly but offers no immediate reply beyond that solemn agreement. The silence between us thickens with anticipation of what’s yet to come—a conversation long overdue and critical for moving forward, whichever direction we ultimately take from here.

With that tacit understanding shared silently through our eyes and posture alone, I prepare mentally for the next phase in our journey—one where old barriers must crumble if there’s any hope of forging something stronger between us.

The room grows darker as the storm outside intensifies, casting long shadows across the floor. The ticking of the clock on the nightstand seems louder now, marking each passing second with an unyielding rhythm.

The hotel room door clicks shut behind us as I close the gap between Marco and myself. The moment hangs heavy with anticipation and hesitation, like rain-heavy air in Amalfi. No words are needed to bridge this silent understanding that whatever happens tonight isn’t just another casual conversation.

"I should have told you earlier," he starts softly, his voice tinged with regret. His eyes lock onto mine, searching for some sign of forgiveness or acceptance beyond what's already been established between us.

I nod slowly, feeling the emotions bubbling just below the surface. This place feels like an ideal setting to break down barriers—not because it’s Amalfi, but because it’s a shared ground where we can finally be honest.

Marco takes a deep breath and runs his hand through his hair as if he needs to gather himself for what's ahead. His gaze flickers over me briefly before settling on the floor, a sign of how daunting this confession is even after all these years. “It… It wasn’t until I saw you here that everything came rushing back.”

His words land softly but echo sharply in my mind. The idea of him burying his past with such effort and being tethered to it by something as simple as a reunion in Amalfi is both profound and unsettling.

The tension wraps around us like an invisible rope, tugging at the edges of our current bond. Yet there’s also an underlying pull guiding us toward deeper levels of honesty and trust—the kind that might just be what we need here in this moment before everything changes again tomorrow.

Without letting him off the hook, I step closer, forcing eye contact despite the sudden surge of vulnerability. “Why didn’t you tell me when it happened?” My voice holds an unspoken challenge to his silence all those years ago and now—to reveal more than just a brother's tragedy but also the man who carries that burden forward.

Marco shifts on his feet, clearly grappling with how much he needs to share in order to lay bare the foundation for what we're trying to build together. His eyes cloud over momentarily before clearing into something steadier and firmer: resolve.

“Because… I wasn’t ready,” he acknowledges quietly but decisively. “Not back then, not now if it weren't for you forcing me.” A rare glimpse of his softer side emerges as he admits this, an honesty that cuts through any pretense or discomfort lingering between us.

I find myself drawn to the sincerity in his eyes despite knowing full well how many layers our relationship has—and will continue—to peel back. With each layer comes a deeper understanding of what we've lost and what we might still salvage if we brave the process fully aware of its risks.

The quiet lengthens out as he prepares for the rest, both of us holding onto this fragile yet potent connection that seems to pulse between us with every heartbeat. The room around us fades away as our conversation delves deeper into uncharted territory where raw emotion reigns supreme and words matter more than ever before.

“Tell me,” I urge gently, reaching out to take his hand. “All of it.”

Marco’s jaw tightens slightly but he nods resolutely. “Okay.” He starts to speak again, his voice softer now that we're both ready to face this together. The first drops of rain begin tapping against the windows—nature's echo of the storm brewing between us.

“Before I can go any further,” Marco says, pausing as if gathering courage for what comes next, “I need you to promise me something.”

A knot forms in my stomach at his words. “What is it?”

He takes another deep breath and looks directly into my eyes. “Promise that no matter what I say tonight, you won’t run away from this.” His voice trembles slightly with the weight of the confession he’s about to make.

“I promise,” I say firmly, squeezing his hand before letting go and stepping back slightly. The rain outside grows heavier, the drops now falling with urgency against the windowpane like nature's own drumbeat urging him on.

“About my brother…” he starts again, his voice so quiet I almost missed it, “he… He died.”

The room goes silent as I process what Marco just said. His eyes are filled with raw emotion, and it’s clear that this confession is more than just about the past—it's about facing the present together.

scenes.content:
Raindrops tap against the window, drumming like impatient fingers on a desk. My pulse kicks sideways inside my chest as I stand at the edge of the hotel room’s balcony, the cool evening air slicing through my thin dress. The weight of tonight’s discussions hangs heavy in the stale indoor space.

Marco approaches from behind me, his voice low but clear: “I should go.”

I nod and offer him an uneasy smile. “Do you want to stay in here?”

“It’s fine.” He stands beside me, looking out at the darkening Amalfi coast.

“Tell me what you’re thinking,” I say, my eyes fixed on the distant lights twinkling along the cliffs.

Marco let the tension leak from my lungs, his breath visible in the cold air before vanishing. “I need time.”

“I understand,” I respond, my fingers curling tightly over the railing, knuckles white against the metal bars.

He turns to me then, his eyes searching mine for answers neither of us can give. “We’ve been here before.” His voice steady but tinged with sadness.

A shudder runs through my body at those words, more than just a physical reaction to cold air. “Your family,” I start carefully, choosing each word like stones for a delicate balance on a seesaw. “My work—”

“I know.” A muscle in his jaw tics as he absorbs my words. The tension between us crackles with unspoken truths, the air thick with questions we dare not voice aloud just yet.

But there’s something else—a spark of defiance rising from within me, refusing to back down even though I recognize the uphill battle ahead. “Are you worried about what they’ll think?” My voice soft but deliberate.

He sighs heavily before looking out at the sea again. “It’s not just them.”

I nod slowly as another wave of unease washes over me—a mixture of fear and anticipation wrapped in a tight ball of knots inside my stomach. He turns back to face me fully now, standing close enough that I can see the honest turmoil etched on his features.

“What are you worried about?” he asks, voice gentle despite the storm brewing around us.

“I’m scared.” No elegant turn of phrase or clever diversion this time.

His expression softens slightly upon hearing my confession. He reaches out and gently cups my cheek with the palm of his hand, tracing where rain streaks have left marks on my skin. “Me too.”

The admission carries a weight that silences everything else around us. We stand there in silence for what feels like an eternity—a strange kind of stillness that allows all the tension to simmer and boil over until it spills out between us.

My lungs stall again as he pulls me closer, his arms wrapping firmly around my waist. For several heartbeats we simply hold each other against the cold wind, our bodies seeking warmth from proximity even amidst the chill. The world around us might be losing clarity with the downpour, but everything feels sharpened and focused between us.

“What do we do now?” I whisper into his shoulder, breath misting in the chill air me tightly against him.

He steps back slightly, hands still resting on my waist. “We figure it out,” he says firmly, eyes locking onto mine with a determination that warms even if reality outside remains cold and wet.

“What does figuring it out look like?”

“It means making choices,” he answers simply but truthfully, “and facing the consequences.”

“And if those choices scare us?”

“They will.” His tone is matter-of-fact rather than dismissive. I nod quietly, absorbing this reality—far from comforting.

My eyes flicker down to his lips as I feel my own brush closer against them in a gesture more intimate than words could convey at the moment.

“I don’t want to let you go,” he murmurs softly, almost but with unmistakable sincerity.

“Neither do I.” The admission leaves my mouth before I can second-guess myself. Gianna’s accusation still echoes in my mind as I step back into the hotel room, leaving Marco behind on the balcony. It's not just this night or these decisions hanging between us now—it's every uncertain future possibility stretching out ahead that's heavy with potential paths diverging based on everything we both choose going forward.

But for right now, standing here together despite the rain and the doubts...it feels like home. His lips brush against mine in a chaste kiss that sends shivers down my spine not just from the cold but from something deeper and more powerful—something awakening within me with each gentle touch and whispered word promising to confront whatever lies ahead hand-in-hand.

The decision is clear: I must face her now or risk losing him forever.

scenes.content:
The files lie scattered across my bed, each one a weight I can’t ignore any longer—a storm of secrets waiting for release. My I can't hold them steady as they hover over Marco’s family divorce file, the paper crinkling beneath my nervous touch. Outside the hotel room window, rain turns to mist, mirroring the fog rolling in between us.

“Marco,” I start, turning from the view and facing him where he sits by the bed. My hands feel clammy, fingers twitching nervously as they rest beside me. “I need to tell you something.”

He looks up slowly, eyes reflecting the intensity of what’s about to spill out. I draw in air slowly, trying to steady myself against the wave crashing inside.

“I have your family's divorce file,” I say bluntly, not wanting to sugarcoat this anymore. My voice trembles slightly despite my best effort to remain calm. “I’ve had it since before—since we last saw each other three years ago.” Marco’s expression hardens, a storm cloud masking any hint of the man from that hidden cove beach just hours earlier.

“Why didn’t you tell me?” His tone is sharp but not accusatory yet—more wounded than angry. I brace myself for what's coming next because the worst isn't usually the surface reaction but rather the aftermath.

“You have every right to be upset,” I begin, meeting his gaze firmly even as my stomach churns with anxiety over where this will lead. “But it’s more than just a simple oversight. It was... complicated.”

His jaw tightens, and he looks away for a moment before turning back sharply, pinning me with an intense stare that makes my heart race.

“Lena,” he starts again but stops mid-sentence as if gathering his thoughts or steeling himself against what follows next. “Why did you do it then?”

My throat clicksening; the answer is both simple and complex. It’s a choice of actions, each one layered with its own set of reasons that can be traced back to that pivotal moment in my life when I took on your family's case.

“Because...” My voice falters as I struggle for words that seem inadequate against this storm cloud hanging between us. “I couldn’t let them tear you and Dante apart just like they did everyone else.”

He narrows his eyes, considering the weight of my words before something softens in his expression—a glimmer of understanding or empathy maybe? But it's fleeting as another layer peels away with his next question.

“And now?” he asks quietly. “Now that this is all coming out?”

“Now,” I say firmly, pushing aside the whirlwind within and focusing on the present reality staring us down coldly like an impending deadline. “We have this wedding tomorrow. We need to figure out how moving forward with this information affects everything.”

He nods reluctantly, still not fully meeting my eye but acknowledging the truth of what’s been revealed. His posture relaxes marginally as he processes this new layer of complication piled on top of all else that's come before.

“I want to believe you,” Marco says after a long pause, his voice softer now with uncertainty rather than anger. “But it complicates everything.”

“Everything is already complicated,” I counter quietly, my words tinged with the same mix of hope and fear we’re both wrestling with. “This revelation doesn't define who we are...but it’s there regardless.”

His silence tells me he's considering this but not fully convinced yet. He leans back against his pillows, pinching the bridge of his nose—a telltale sign of stress or frustration.

“I know,” I add softly after a moment, trying to convey understanding and support rather than defensiveness. “But here we are, facing it together.”

Marco looks at me steadily for a long moment before sighing deeply. The storm outside is easing into rain showers now, mirroring the shift within our shared space.

“We’ll figure it out,” I say quietly but with resolve. He gives a small smile that doesn’t quite reach his eyes yet, though there’s something promising in its tentative warmth. It's enough for now, this fragile peace we’ve found despite everything that looms ahead.

I sit down beside Marco on the bed then, pulling my knees up close as we both fall silent once more but with less tension than before—a silent solidarity that promises perseverance amidst uncertainty yet to be fully understood or resolved between us just yet. The cool linen sheets feel like an anchor in a stormy sea, grounding me to this moment.

Sitting beside Marco on the bed, I let myself be still for a moment. The room is quiet except for the rain tapping against the window and the distant crash of waves below. My fingers trace the rough cotton bunched up from his restless tossing earlier.

The gap separating us feels heavy with uncertainty and doubt. Despite this weight, Marco’s hand finds mine, intertwining our fingers as if offering a silent vow of support. His touch grounds me when my mind starts to drift away.

“I can’t blame you for being upset,” I murmur. The words taste bitter on my tongue—unwelcome truths I never expected to say out loud. “It’s not exactly something an ex expects.” He tightens his grip slightly, a reassurance that feels more urgent than soothing right now.

Heat gathers in the quiet beneath the surface of this fragile truce we’ve established. Marco shifts uncomfortably beside me, his eyes flickering from side to side as if searching for something solid amidst the emotional turmoil swirling between us.

“Damn it,” he grumbles into the darkness, frustration and disappointment lacing every word. “I just don’t understand how you could keep it a secret.”

My chest constricts at the weight of his words, but I force myself to focus on my breathing—inhale, exhale, inhale, exhale. Each breath becomes a mantra, an anchor in this tumultuous sea pulling me under.

“Lena,” he starts again after another pregnant pause, his voice softer now but no less charged with unspoken questions and accusations. “Why did you stay silent for so long? Why didn’t you come clean?”

I twist my fingers around each other, trying to find the right words amidst the jumbled thoughts racing through my mind.

“Because...” My voice trails off like it’s unwilling to finish this line of thought out loud. “I was scared,” I admit eventually, the sharp taste of self-disgust and regret lacing every syllable. “Scared that telling you might push us further apart.”

Marco’s something calculating crosses my face slightly at my confession, a shadow flickering across his face like he’s battling internal conflict visible only to me in this hushed moment between us.

“Do you think avoiding the problem makes it go away?” He asks, his tone clipped but not harsh—a knife’s edge of accusation thinly veiled behind a facade of calm inquiry. “Because that certainly hasn’t been my experience.”

His words sting like salt water in an open wound and I’m forced to acknowledge the painful truth they hold.

“Maybe you’re right,” I concede quietly, looking down at our entwined hands as if they might offer some kind of guidance or solution. “But sometimes staying silent feels like the safer option.”

Marco lets out a humorless chuckle that sends shivers along my spine—it’s a sound charged with resignation and defeat more than amusement.

“Safe,” he repeats dryly, his voice dripping sarcasm. “Yeah, I understand keeping secrets feels safer in the moment, but it doesn’t solve anything long-term.”

He releases my hand then as if suddenly unwilling to offer comfort anymore; instead pushing himself up from the bed so quickly that his movement causes the sheets to rustle and rattle behind him like a warning.

“I need some air,” he declares simply before exiting without another word, leaving me with nothing but the echo of unresolved the unspoken hovers heavy in my ears.

A fine tremor runs to my nails slightly, I rise from the bed and make my way wordlessly towards the balcony door that leads out onto the night air. There is comfort in being alone for a moment amidst these unfamiliar surroundings—to ponder this new reality of unresolved feelings and unspoken truths—and with each step forward, I find myself leaning more into bitter cynicism rather than hopeful acceptance.

As raindrops soak through my clothing and bite at my skin like tiny daggers piercing protective layers, the cold serves as an apt metaphor for the chill settling inside me. It’s only after taking several deep breaths to steady myself against this oncoming storm that I begin to process what transpires here tonight—no amount of denial or avoidance will make us any less entangled in each other's lives.

And with that realization comes another: there is no going back now from the path we've chosen. This retreat into solitude and silence is merely a temporary respite before facing whatever lies ahead head-on, together—or apart. The choice between those two paths still remains uncertain but one thing becomes clear amidst all this turmoil: avoidance never solved anything.

The rain continues to pour as I stand there contemplating my next move in this complex dance of emotions, but it’s no longer the only wetness threatening to overwhelm me—my eyes well up with unshed tears that threaten to spill freely down my cheeks at any moment. Yet amidst these fragile boundaries breaking and reassembling themselves once more, a spark inside ignites; an ember of hope flickering despite the darkness encroaching all around.

For now, this retreat into cynicism offers some semblance of safety from confronting painful truths head-on, but it won’t last forever. The only real question left is whether we are ready to embrace whatever comes next—or if this quiet space offers us both a reprieve long enough for one final chance at healing and reconciliation before moving on separately once more.

I steady myself, the rain now a soothing rhythm against my skin, as I decide that no matter what happens next, I need to be honest with myself—and him. With this thought in mind, I turn back towards the bedroom door, ready to face whatever comes next.

scenes.content:
Marco’s hand brushes against mine, sending a jolt down my spine. I pull back and collapse onto the couch on the opposite side of the room, arms wrapped tight around my knees. The air thickens with unsaid words and unaddressed emotions.

A framed photo catches my eye—us at the beach, laughter frozen in time. Marco suggested this trip to reconnect after a tough patch, but now I wonder if it was ever meant to be more than a bittersweet attempt to mend old wounds.

“Are you okay?” His voice breaks through the silence, tinged with genuine concern and something else—vulnerability that makes me pause. He leans against the back of his chair, fingers tapping nervously on the armrest.

“I know.” I exhale heavily, the weight of this moment pressing against my chest. Guilt and regret linger like a shadow cast by an unmovable object. “But what are we supposed to do now?”

Marco stands up, his silhouette dark against the moonlit room. He walks toward me but stops short of touching me. “We figure it out,” he says softly, almost speaking only to himself. His eyes scan my face, searching for answers.

I hesitate, my gaze fixed on the floor between us. The thought of leaning into this uncertainty again is daunting, but turning away feels even more painful. “What does that mean?” I ask quietly, my voice in a low voice.

He steps closer and reaches out tentatively as if offering support. “It means we stop running.” He sits down beside me on the couch, our shoulders brushing in a silence that’s both comforting and unsettling. Marco reaches for my hand, intertwining our fingers loosely—a gesture of solidarity rather than possession.

“Can you really mean it?” I say, my voice steady despite the turmoil inside me. “We can’t just erase everything,” I point out, my eyes never leaving his. “The past isn't something we can ignore.”

“No.” His eyes meet mine with an intensity that feels both familiar and newly invigorating. “But maybe we can start to heal from it.”

His hand tightens around mine—an unspoken promise of mutual support.

“I didn’t mean any harm,” he says after a moment, his thumb rubbing gently across my knuckles. “But I see now how much it must have hurt you to find out.”

“It did.” My voice is tight, the pain still raw but no longer overwhelming. “But it’s not just about that.”

“What else?” He turns slightly toward me, his body angled in a way that feels protective without being suffocating.

I hesitate for another moment, weighing my words carefully. The stakes feel higher now, the potential for either healing or further damage real and palpable.

“It’s about whether we’re willing to be honest with each other,” I finally say, my eyes never leaving his. “And if that honesty can lead us somewhere better.”

“No.” He says slowly, a small but significant admission in his expression. “But maybe we can start to heal from it.” His hand tightens around mine—a silent promise of mutual support.

“Then let’s take the first step toward something new,” I say, my voice steady and resolute. He nods, his grip on my hand tightening slightly as if he’s trying to hold onto this fragile moment of clarity.

Marco leans in slightly, his warm breath grazing my cheek as he speaks softly once more. “Alright,” I murmur in agreement, my hand squeezing his gently.

The room remains quiet as we hold each other's gaze, the weight of our decision hanging between us like a delicate balance waiting to tip one way or the other.

Marco leans back against the couch, eyes closing briefly before he looks at me with renewed determination. “I just don’t know if I’m ready for that,” he admits, breaking the silence and adding a new layer of complexity to our conversation.

The tension slowly eases, replaced by a sense of quiet resolve. As dawn approaches, the darkness starts to lift around us, and I find myself strangely comforted—ready for whatever lies ahead if only because we’ll be navigating it side by side.

“Alright,” I say with a small smile, my fingers tightening around his in reassurance. “Let’s take this one step at a time.”

In that simple act of acceptance and mutual commitment, a new beginning seems not just possible but inevitable—a fragile yet hopeful start to healing old wounds and forging a path forward together.

But as the first light of dawn filters through the window, I can’t shake the feeling that there are still shadows lurking in our future. And as Marco’s hand loosens its grasp on mine, uncertainty stirs within me once again.

scenes.content:
The door to the wine pavilion swings open abruptly, knocking me off balance as Marco storms in. My pulse kicks sideways as I stumble after him into the dimly lit room where our fragile peace is shattered by his anger.

“Marco,” my voice shakes with the weight of unspoken words and unresolved tensions. “What’s going on?”

He whirls around to face me, his eyes blazing with a mix of frustration and something deeper, more raw. “How can you even pretend everything’s fine?” he demands in a low, dangerous tone.

I close the distance between us, my footsteps echoing against the stone floor. The something electric passes between us in the air like an electrical storm. “Marco,” I repeat, trying to calm him with a soothing note in my voice. “Hold on about this.”

He takes another step closer until there’s barely any space left between us. His breath is hot against my face as he leans in, his eyes burning into mine.

“We will,” he growls through clenched teeth, “but not now. Not here.” He whirls away from me once more, pacing back and forth across the small room like a caged animal, his hands balled into fists at his sides.

I watch him, my own frustration bubbling up inside me. This relentless dance of avoidance and confrontation was becoming unbearable. “Marco,” I try again, this time with less patience. “We can’t keep pushing each other away.”

He stops mid-stride, turning to face me once more, his eyes filled with a swirl of emotions that made my chest ache with understanding.

“We have work to do,” I point out, reminding us both of the pressing reality of our situation. “The wedding is just days away, and we need to get this right.”

He steps forward, closing the distance between us with slow, measured strides. I meet him halfway, stopping when he does, our breaths mingling in the thin air.

“I know,” Marco’s voice carries a soft warmth despite his tight control, “but it’s not just about the wedding.”

“True.” My words are clipped but truthful. So much more needs to be unraveled between us, but for now, we have a deadline to meet. If we fail, my sister’s dream could crumble.

He leans in slightly, his eyes searching mine. “Don't walk away yet—really talk. About everything.”

My stomach clenches as the weight of our history presses down on me, each breath heavy with the burden of unfinished conversations. My hand moves toward him without thinking, squeezing gently for a moment before falling away.

“Alright.” I murmur in agreement.

Marco guides us toward one of the living room chairs, and I sink into it, feeling the soft fabric against my skin. He sits across from me, his posture rigid as if bracing himself for impact.

“Do you remember that wine tasting we did at the start of all this?” he asks, breaking the tension with a touch of nostalgia.

“Yes,” I breathe out, recalling the crisp hillside air and the way our fingers brushed against each other’s. “It was one of the first times we really connected.”

Marco nods, his expression easing slightly. “We should do it again. Let’s take this moment to reconnect in a place that feels familiar but renewed. Maybe it’ll help us find some clarity.”

I consider his words, seeing the sincerity behind them. There is no avoiding our past or the ties that bind us together, but perhaps there is a way forward—one where we rebuild from shared experiences and mutual understanding.

“Lead the way,” I say, standing up with renewed purpose.

Marco rises, offering a hand to help me straighten my dress. Our fingers intertwine for just a moment before he releases me. The touch sends shivers down my spine, but this time they feel less like fear and more like anticipation of what lies ahead.

Together, we step out onto the villa’s stone patio, the warm Mediterranean sun casting golden rays through the olive trees. As we walk toward the vineyards nestled at the base of a hill, I feel Marco's presence beside me—a constant anchor amidst the swirling emotions inside my chest.

“Ready?” he asks softly, glancing over to check if I’m okay with this next step forward.

“As ready as I’ll ever be,” I respond, lifting my chin slightly. We move toward our destination in unison, each taking comfort from the other’s company without needing words of reassurance.

As we approach the wine pavilion, a sense of calm settles over me. The old chemistry between us is alive and potent as ever, but this time it's tempered by a newfound understanding. We are facing our fears head-on now, determined to find a way through them together.

Marco stops in his tracks, turning away from the pavilion. “I can’t do this,” he says, his voice rough with emotion. I feel my heart clench as he refuses to engage, forcing me to confront my feelings.

“What’s wrong?” I ask, my hand reaching out for his arm.

“We have too much history. Too many unresolved issues.” He turns back to face me, his eyes filled with pain and regret. “I need time.”

His refusal hits me like a punch in the gut. The warmth of our earlier connection evaporates, leaving only cold reality behind. If we can’t work together now, my sister’s wedding could be ruined.

“We don’t have that luxury,” I say firmly, pulling away from him.

“You’re right.” He nods, but his eyes still hold a weight of sorrow. “Let’s handle this first.”

The vineyard worker rushes toward us with urgent news as we start back toward the villa.

“Signorina Castillo,” he calls out, “there’s been an issue with the caterers. They’ve canceled their services at the last minute.”

My heart sinks. This is exactly what we feared—the wedding could fall apart without proper coordination.

“We need to handle this together.” Marco says from behind me, his voice resolute despite his earlier refusal.

“Let’s do it,” I say, stepping forward and taking control of the situation. The stakes are now higher than ever, and there's no turning back.

scenes.content:
The cool evening air brushes against my skin as I step onto the balcony of the Amalfi Villa; Marco follows close behind. We lean on the railing together, looking out at the twinkling lights below—a stark contrast to the weighty conversation ahead.

"Do you ever feel like we're walking back into a storm?" he asks quietly, his eyes roving the horizon but avoiding mine.

I tighten my grip on the railing, considering his words. "Sometimes it feels that way. But this time, there's something different."

Marco turns toward me, his expression guarded yet curious. “What’s changed?”

“Before, we were pulled back by unresolved emotions and past regrets,” I explain, lifting my chin to meet his eyes squarely. “Now, we’re facing our fears together instead of running away from them.” My voice softens slightly as I speak.

He nods slowly, the corners of his mouth twitching as if he’s trying not to smile. “You always could articulate things so clearly,” Marco says with a soft chuckle.

“Yeah, well...” I reply, my lips curling slightly in response. “Divorce law does that to you.”

His eyes flicker with amusement before falling back into seriousness. He steps closer, his gaze unwavering. "But it’s not who you are. You’re more than someone dealing with the fallout of broken marriages." His words carry a gentle sincerity.

Warmth spreads through me at his words. It isn’t easy talking about my career when people dismiss it as just negative consequences.

“Thanks,” I say softly, letting out a grateful breath. “It affects how I see relationships.” I look away momentarily, the weight of those thoughts lingering in what hung unspoken.

He draws closer, placing a hand on my back briefly before removing it. "By being honest with ourselves and each other."

I nod, feeling the pull toward him intensify but reminding myself that this isn’t about ease; it’s about growth.

“Lena,” Marco says as we enter the main room, his voice carrying an unspoken question.

“Yes?”

“This wedding planning hasn’t been easy on either of us. But now, with everything out in the open...” He trails off, searching my expression for something.

“I know,” I reply firmly, meeting his gaze squarely. “We’ve faced more than a few challenges.”

Marco pauses, then continues: “But being here together again? It feels like we’re starting to rewrite the stories we thought were set in stone.” His hand brushes against mine briefly before he steps back.

A shiver runs through me—both thrilling and terrifying as I realize the potential for either ruin or redemption. My lungs stall slightly.

“We have that power,” I agree softly, my voice steady but tinged with emotion.

He reaches out, his fingers brushing against mine in a fleeting touch of reassurance. "For better or worse, we’re making our own choices now."

“Together,” I insist, locking eyes with him firmly his hand briefly before letting go.

With the weight of our conversation and emotions lingering between us, we head toward the wine pavilion. The evening breeze follows us like a silent reminder of all we’ve walked through together.

As we reach the pavilion, soft rustling leaves and distant laughter greet us warmly. Inside, a small table is set up with glasses filled with an inviting red wine.

“Looking forward to this?” Marco asks, his tone casual yet intimate as he pours each of us a glass.

I take mine gratefully, raising it in a silent toast before taking a sip. “More than ready,” I say softly.

With the weight of our conversation and emotions lingering between us, we sit down to begin anew—this time with clearer intentions and no illusions about what lies ahead.

The warm evening air carries a hint of salt from the sea as I step into the pavilion. Rows of wine bottles line the shelves behind me, each one a testament to the rich history of Italian vineyards. My fingers grip my glass tightly; the cool surface provides an anchor in this dizzying moment.

"Shall we start with something light?" Marco asks, breaking the silence as he pours two glasses from a bottle marked "Chardonnay."

I nod slightly and take mine gratefully, watching him pause for a brief second before filling his own glass. The golden liquid reflects the soft glow of lanterns hanging above us, casting flickering shadows against our faces.

"Ever change your mind about my profession?" I ask softly, lifting my glass in a silent toast.

He meets my gaze with a mixture of curiosity and something more complex beneath the surface. "It's not exactly what I'd call a career," he replies, his tone laced with an undercurrent of tension that unsettles me.

"I know it’s... controversial,” I say carefully, choosing each word with precision. “But you didn’t pick this path by choice either.”

Marco push the air out and leans back against the bar counter behind him, running a hand through his hair before replying. "True. It just feels like there's always more at stake when it comes to family."

His comment hits me hard; the echo of my own struggles with legal battles and divorce papers for his family still lingers in my mind.

"Speaking of stakes," I continue, setting my glass down slowly on the counter’s surface before meeting his eyes again. “Why did you choose me as your planner? Were you just using me?”

His expression hardens momentarily, but then softens as he considers my question. "I wasn't thinking about that back then,” Marco admits, a shadow passing over his face. “But now? I have to admit it's crossed my mind."

"That’s fair," I say with a nod.

We sit in silence for a moment, the everything unsaid presses down heavy between us like an invisible curtain. The soft hum of the wine pavilion filters through the stillness, each sip drawing out our uncomfortable truth.

"Is there something specific you need to know from me before we move forward?" he asks, his voice steady despite the palpable tension.

I fill my lungs and think about all the unspoken questions that have been swirling in my mind since this unexpected reunion. “Your thoughts on us moving past this,” I respond quietly, looking up at him with an intensity born of desperation to understand. “Do you see any future here?”

He pauses again, his eyes searching mine for answers we both know he can’t find.

"Right now?" Marco sighs, closing gaze briefly before reopening it and focusing on me once more. "I need time to process everything. But I’m also... open."

Those few words cut through the haze of uncertainty like a sharp knife. My pulse kicks sideways as his hand reaches out, hovering just inches from mine.

"I understand," I say softly, my voice under his breath. “We both need space.”

As he pulls back slightly, our fingers brush in an electric moment that sends shivers down my spine. The old chemistry between us is alive and potent as ever, but now tempered by honesty and the fragile thread of understanding.

The moment stretches out before us like a bridge, each step forward carefully considered. Our eyes lock once more, a shared agreement silently forged in this quiet camaraderie.

"Let’s make sure we get through this wedding," I muse aloud, turning my attention back to our surroundings as the weight of those words settles within me. “For whatever reason,” I add quietly, looking up at him with a mix of resolve and hope reflecting in his eyes.

“Agreed.” His voice is steady now, no longer weighed down by the burden of uncertainty that had clouded us moments earlier.

As we finish our glasses and make plans to focus on more immediate concerns, my mind begins to unravel some of the knots holding back this newfound clarity. We are navigating uncharted territory together, but with shared purpose and a fragile sense of unity that feels both necessary and fragile amidst these turbulent waters.

In this moment, I realize we have taken our first steps toward something greater than just another professional obligation or lingering resentment from the past.

The air around us shifts again as we stand to leave, each action now bearing less tension but still filled with a sense of cautious optimism—an unwritten agreement that there will be more conversations to come, where this foundation of honesty can grow and thrive. We exit together into the night, leaving behind the warmth and light of the pavilion for the cool, starlit sky.

My I press my palms flat against my thighs slightly as I reach for Marco’s, feeling the cool night air bite at my skin. The Amalfi Villa looms dark against the starlit sky, its silence echoing the weight of our conversation. We sit on the balcony, glasses of wine forgotten between us as unspoken words hang heavy in the air.

The night air chills my skin, carrying jasmine from nearby gardens. Marco and I sit on the Amalfi Villa balcony with glasses of wine in hand. We’ve been more open tonight than ever before, but an unspoken the weight of it sits between us between us like a thick fog.

Marco drains his glass and sets it down, turning to look out at Positano’s glittering lights. "I was twenty-two when my brother died," he says softly. His voice is steady despite the pain flickering in his eyes. I ache for him but can offer no comfort other than silence.

"I’ve always thought..." He pauses, running a hand through his hair before continuing. "That if he were still here, everything would be different." A heavy sigh escapes him as he turns to face me fully.

"You’d have your life back," I say quietly, mirroring the thoughts swirling in my mind. He nods, his gaze unwavering on mine for a moment before breaking away.

"I’ve always wondered what it was like for you after everything."

I shift nervously in my seat as I admit my age. "When I first began handling divorces at twenty-three, I thought I’d become numb to the pain—and maybe I did. But that doesn’t mean it never hurts."

Marco’s expression softens slightly at my words, a trace of understanding crossing his face.

"Do you ever regret your choice?" he asks carefully. Anger, sorrow, acceptance swirl in me like a maelstrom. "Sometimes," I reply honestly, watching as his my gaze sharpens thoughtfully.

Silence falls around us again, thicker and more charged.

"What will you do when this wedding is over?"

"I don’t know," I admit after a moment of internal debate. The uncertainty settles like stone in my gut. "I can’t stay here forever."

His I study him harder briefly before softening. He reaches out to touch my hand but then pulls back, his gaze searching mine. "Would you consider staying a little longer?" His voice is sincere and unguarded.

"What does that mean for us?"

He looks away momentarily, moonlight catching on the lines etched around his eyes. "I don’t know if I can let go," he admits quietly. The question of starting over stirs both allure and terror within me. "Neither can I," I confess aloud.

His gaze returns to mine, searching for something vulnerable and raw that I’ve kept hidden until now. The moment stretches tense between us, thick with unspoken words and feelings.

"Do you ever wish we could just start over?" His question is a low murmur in his throat. "Sometimes," I whisper, looking away from those piercing blue eyes.

As he reaches out and gently turns my face back towards him, I feel the promise in his touch. "We can make something new together."

My lungs stall at his words, despite the cool night air. He reaches for my hand, and I allow it to rest there, not fully ready but acknowledging the possibility.

"Just promise," I say with a tremor in my voice, "that we’ll take things one step at a time."

His smile is soft and reassuring as he promises, "I will." His thumb brushes against the back of my hand, sending a shiver down my spine.

The grip on our hands tightens slightly, promising more than words ever could. We’ve opened up to each other tonight, shared fears and hopes, but there’s still so much left unsaid—so many questions lingering beneath the surface.

Dawn begins to creep over Amalfi Cove as we sit in a comfortable silence for a while longer, letting everything settle into us before making our next move. I know this is just the beginning of our journey together. My heart flutters nervously at the thought but there’s also an undeniable sense of peace when looking at Marco.

"I’m ready for whatever comes next," I say with quiet resolve, lifting his hand to press a soft kiss against it before turning back towards the bedroom door. "Let's face it together."

Marco’s eyes brighten in agreement, following close behind as we step off the balcony and into our new beginning.

The jasmine blooms outside my villa send their sweet scent wafting inside as I step off the balcony, the cool marble flooring chilling my bare feet. My stomach tightens with knots, and I turn toward the bedroom door, ready for another showdown—or maybe something more.

"Wait," Marco’s voice stops me just as I reach for the doorknob. His tone is cautious but not hostile, making me pause and look back at him. He stands there with his hands in his pockets, shoulders slightly hunched, a posture that shows discomfort yet also acceptance.

"I need to tell you something," he says slowly, eyes searching mine. "It might not be what you want to hear."

My the world hitches for a second as I step toward him again, curiosity and nervous anticipation building inside me. "Let's get this over with then." The words come out sharper than intended.

Marco’s gaze flickers to the balcony door before he steps further into the room. His movements are deliberate and measured, like someone preparing for an inevitable storm. He runs a hand through his hair, smoothing it back from his forehead before stopping abruptly at one of the windows overlooking the cliffside gardens below. He leans against the window frame, arms crossed over his chest.

"I found something," he says, voice steady but tense. "Something you might not have expected."

My lungs stall as I edge closer to him, standing just a step away yet feeling miles apart from the connection we shared moments ago. His eyes are fixed on mine, but there’s a distance between us now that wasn’t there before.

"Why did you keep this from me?" I ask after a few moments of silence. "Was it because of how it made you feel?"

Marco shifts uncomfortably, his eyes meeting mine with more conviction now. “No,” he says firmly. “It’s because I didn’t want to believe what was in here until I had no choice.”

He doesn’t need to say more; the look in his eyes and the tension in his posture convey everything that’s unsaid but clear.

“Go on,” I say quietly, trying to keep my voice steady despite the storm brewing within me. Marco nods, his expression resolute yet guarded. “This file has been in your possession since then.”

I nod slowly, feeling the gravity of this moment pressing down on us both. The envelope feels heavier by the second.

“Thank you,” he says quietly after another moment of silence between us. “For being here.”

I look at him, seeing more than just a planner or an ex-lover in his eyes. I see someone who’s been hurt and afraid but also brave enough to confront their past once again.

“I’m here,” I say softly, meeting his gaze with resolve. “Let’s face it together.”

Marco steps closer then, closing the final distance between us. He places one hand on my shoulder in a gesture that feels both familiar and new. His touch is steady despite the tension we both carry—his fingers pressing into muscle, connecting us as two halves of something whole.

“What’s inside this envelope?”

He hesitates before turning away slightly once more, reaching into the envelope and pulling out a single piece of paper with trembling fingers. As he unfolds it slowly, revealing its contents, I feel my own heart pause in anticipation.

"Read this," Marco says quietly, holding the sheet out for me to take from him. "It's our reality now."

I grasp it carefully, seeing that it is indeed part of a file detailing his parents’ divorce proceedings—a document that encapsulates all the hurt and loss he has faced but also lays him bare. The words on the page are stark—cold, clinical statements defining the end of his childhood home.

"This is it," Marco says as a breeze from outside brings with it a hint of sea salt and freedom. "Let's move forward."

I nod slowly, taking one final look at him before setting my gaze on the piece of paper he has handed me—a tangible representation of where we stand now but also what lies ahead.

"We will," I say firmly, meeting his eyes again.

With one deep breath, I step toward the balcony door, feeling a shift within me from confronting this obstacle together with Marco. It’s not just about moving forward; it’s about understanding why we can’t go back and embracing what brought us here.

"Wait," he says softly, reaching out to stop me from opening it.

"What is it?" I ask, turning back to him. The document in my hand feels like a burden that could either hold us back or propel us forward.

"We can't destroy it." My voice holds firm resolve as I meet his gaze. He nods slowly, understanding dawning in his eyes as he steps closer to me again.

With one deep breath, I step out onto the balcony, holding both the document and Marco’s hand tightly as we look out at the Amalfi coast together.

scenes.content:
Marco’s hand tightens around mine as we step off the balcony onto the smooth stones leading down to the beach. The path is narrow and winding, faintly lit by the waning moon above. I can feel his warmth next to me; this moment isn’t about questions or explanations anymore.

I guide us down towards where we first kissed, my pulse kicks sideways under the weight of everything that hangs between us. The night air is cool against my skin as I lead him to our secret cove, untouched by tourists, filled with the soothing sound of lapping waves. We’ve faced too much already tonight—confessions, secrets, a shared history complex and comforting.

“I thought this beach was just for memories,” Marco murmurs, his voice warmer than ever as he gazes out at the moonlit water. “But it seems like there’s more to be found here.”

“Yeah.” My words catch in the rhythm of the waves. “More than we bargained for, but maybe what we need.”

His hand finds mine again, intertwining our fingers tightly.

We stand in silence, only the gentle rush of water and our breathing breaking it. Time feels as if it’s slowed down to a crawl, each second stretching out into minutes.

“Do you think he knew?” Marco asks quietly after a while, breaking the spell of silence that had settled over us like a blanket. His eyes search mine in the shadowy light.

“I do,” I whisper back, looking away briefly but then meeting his gaze again. “But sometimes it’s easier to believe they didn’t know than to face how much they might have suffered.”

“True.” Marco nods slowly, a rare vulnerability settling into his expression. He lets out a shuddering breath and steps closer to me, closing the distance between us. Our hearts beat in tandem as he reaches up to brush some hair away from my face.

“I’m wrong,” he says again, his voice steadying with each word. “About you, about everything.”

His words stir emotions I hadn’t known were there—a mix of relief and sorrow washing over me. This admission—it’s the first step in letting go of all that had held us back.

“Then let’s make it right,” I answer softly, moving closer to him his eyes searching mine for any sign of hesitation or doubt.

He nods again, pressing his forehead against mine briefly before pulling me into an embrace. His arms wrap around my waist, and I press into him; the warmth from his body seeps through to mine.

“I’ve missed this,” he murmurs between kisses, his hands threading through my hair as he deepens our kiss.

“Me too.” I reply breathlessly, moving closer still as his mouth explores every inch of skin within reach. His lips leave mine briefly and travel down my neck, sending shivers through me with each contact.

“What do you want from here?” he asks, pausing to look into my eyes for an answer.

“I want to move forward,” I reply honestly, pressing another kiss into the spot where his mouth lingers. “I want us.”

“And what about Amalfi? Our wedding planning?”

“We’ll take it one day at a time.” Feeling a mix of emotions well up as we face our future head-on, his arms tighten around me once more.

“Okay,” he nods again, this time with conviction in his tone. “Agreed.”

I tilt my head back slightly as he begins to kiss along the curve of my jawline, each sensation sparking new levels of intimacy and understanding between us. He pauses momentarily, looking deep into my eyes before continuing.

His lips leave mine once more and travel down my neck again; I shiver under his touch, feeling every inch of skin come alive with a new kind of fire and purpose.

“Are you ready?” he breathes into my ear, his voice sending shivers up my spine once more.

I feel the words forming on my lips but before I can answer, Marco pulls back slightly. His eyes hold mine as if seeking permission, and in that moment, it’s clear we’ve reached a tipping point where nothing else matters except for this one decision.

“Are you ready?” he asks again, his voice almost inaudible.

scenes.content:
The document in my hand feels heavy as I stare out at the crashing waves below, a stark reminder of Marco’s family legacy and our shared history. The sound of footsteps behind me startles me into turning around sharply to see him approaching, his presence like an anchor in turbulent seas.

Stepping into the cozy café near Villa Caruso, I scan the room for her and find her seated in a corner booth, sipping coffee. Her presence is like a chill gust on an otherwise warm day, reminding me that not everyone here pretends to be pulling together.

As I approach, she looks up with sharp eyes.

"Lawrence," I greet coolly, taking a seat across from her.

"I heard about your career choice," she says, leaning forward. Her tone is pointed and cutting. "Divorce law? Really?"

"Really." I lace my fingers around the handle of my coffee mug and meet her stare head-on. "Why does everyone assume there's an easy way out if you work in divorce law?"

"You represent people getting out of marriages," she says, raising a brow. "You must see the ugliness up close."

"Marriages can be beautiful," I counter, setting my mug down firmly and leaning forward. "But they can also be toxic fumes choking every good thing. Some divorces are merciful escapes from living hell."

Lawrence’s jaw tightens visibly as she processes my words.

"And what about the emotional toll?" she asks, my voice low but steady.

"Every client has regrets," I say, "and every divorce leaves scars. But there's also hope in moving forward, even if it means facing hard truths." My voice doesn’t waver despite the lingering tension between us.

Lawrence leans back and crosses her arms, silence stretching out as she grapples with my argument. Finally, she nods slowly but still looks unimpressed by my rationale. "Fine," she says through clenched teeth. "But I doubt you can keep your heart in it."

"I may not have a rose-tinted view of marriage," I counter, "but that doesn’t mean I lack empathy or see no value in the fights to make them work." She shakes my head dismissively and stands up abruptly, signaling she’s done with this exchange. As I watch her leave, I can't help but feel a twinge of satisfaction mixed with unease.

Back at Villa Caruso, my thoughts drift back to the document in my hand—a relic from Marco's family's darker days that brought us face-to-face with our pasts. With every page turning into another painful reminder, I know I need time alone before facing him again. Slipping quietly away from everyone else, I find myself by the villa walls, leaning against them and gazing through a high window overlooking Amalfi’s steep cliffs. The sound of crashing waves below provides a soothing backdrop to my internal turmoil.

When Marco appears beside me moments later, his presence feels like an anchor in rough seas. But I can't let emotions dictate every move just yet; this document and what it represents needs careful handling first.

"Still thinking about this?" he asks softly, nudging my shoulder with his own.

I nod slowly but keep the document safely tucked away from view. "Yeah. There’s a lot I’ve been trying to process."

He offers me a small smile that still seems somewhat guarded. "And there's not just this," he notes, reminding me of everything we've shared since arriving here—the revelations, struggles, and tentative steps toward mutual healing.

I glance up at him through my lashes, the weight of all our history bearing down even as I try to push forward. This document is more than paperwork from his family—it’s a loaded symbol demanding careful confrontation now that we’re both ready for it. It’s about what trust has been restored and how far we're willing to take the risk together.

With another deep breath, I push my reservations aside temporarily in favor of pressing forward with renewed determination towards resolving this pivotal issue under Amalfi skies that have witnessed so much between us already.
